Arthur of Brytayn.

The hystory of the most noble and valiant knight Arthur of little brytayne,
translated out of frensshe in to englushe by the noble Johan bourghcher knight
lord Barners, newly Imprynted.



Here follows the translatours prologue.
FOr as much as it is delectable to all humayne nature to read and to here
these ancient noble Hystoryes of the chyualrous Feats and marcyall Prowesses
of the vyctoryous Knights of times paste whose tryumphaunt deeds if writing
were not should be had cleue out of remembrance. And also because that
ydelnesse is reputed to be the mother of al vices, wherefore somewhat in
eschewynge thereof and in the way of lowli erudycyon and learning I John
Bourghchere knight lord Berners have enterprysed to translate out of frensshe
in to our maternal tongue a noble hystory making mencyon of the famous deeds
of the right valiant knight Arthur son and heir to the noble duke of
Brytayne and of the fair lady Florence daughter and heir to the mighty
Emendus king of the noble realm of Soroloys, and of the great trouble that
they endured or they attained to the perfourmaunce of their virtuous amorous
desyers, for first they overcame many hard and strange adventures the which
as to our humayne reason should seem to be incredible, wherefore after that I
had begone this said process I have determined to have left and given up my
labor for I thought it should have be reputed but a folly in me to translate
beseming such a feigned matter wherein seems to be so many vnpossybylytees, how
be it than I called again to my remembrance that I had read and seen many a
sondrye volume of diverse noble hystoryes wherein were contained the redoubted
deeds of the ancient inuynsyble conquerours and of other right famous knights
who acheued many a strange and wonderful adventure the which by plain
letter as to our understanding should seem in a manner to be supernatural,
wherefore I thought that this present treatise might as well be reputed for
troth as some of those. And also I doubted not but that the first auctour of
this book devised it not with out some manner of truth or virtuous intent, the
which consyderacyons and other gave me again audacyte to continue forth my
fryste purpose till I had fynysshed this said book, not presumynge that I have
reduced it in to fresshe ornate polysshed english, for I know my self
insuffycyent in the facondyous art of rethoryke, nor also I am but a lerner of
the language of frensshe how be it I trust my simple reason has led me to
the understanding of the true sentence of the matter, according to the which
I have followed as nere as I could desiring all the reders and herers thereof to
take this my rude tra^slacion in gre and if any fault be to lay it to mine
uncunning and derke Ingnorau^ce and to mynysshe, add, or augmet as they shall
find cause requysyte, and in their so doing I shall pray to god that after
this vain and transytory life he may bring them unto the perdurable Joy of
heaven. Amen.

Thus ends the translatours prologue.
Here after follows the table of this present history.
The first chapyter makes mencyon of the birth of the noble kynght Arthur
sone and heir to the duke of Brytayne. Capitulo.i. Folio.i. How ye duke of
brytayne delivered his so^e Arthur to the governance of a prudent knight named
sir Gouernar who did ensygne hi^ in all goodly manners and deeds of arms so
that afterward there was none like unto him. ca. ii. folio.i. How Arthur found
in the forest a noble lady without socour, and with her a fair young maid her
daughter named Iehannet before a little lodge the which they had made of ye
branches of the trees And how yt Arthur was amorous of the said Iehannet.
caplo. iii. folio.i How Arthur caused to be delivered to Ieha^net and her mother
the revenues that bleo^ged to the slange or ponde of the foreste, whereby there
stood a fair goodly place of pleasure, and afterward Arthur did oftentimes
resort thither to pass the time with them. cap. iiii. folio.ii. How
within.viii. days after Arthur and Gouernar went to ye stange to se ye lady
and Iehannet her daughter. ca. v. folio.iii. How that the duke and duches took
counsel to mary their son Arthur, and how they sent their steward to the
lady Luke of ostryge for to demand her daughter for Arthur. cap. vi. folio
iiii. How the seen shall demanded ye daughter of ostrige for Arthur of
brytayne, the which request with great joy was granted him. capitulo.vii. fo.
eodem How yt Arthur was sore displeased for that his fader would mary hi^ to ye
daughter of ostrige because it was said she was of ill governance. ca. viii.
folio.iiii. How yt Arthur went to se Iehannet and declared to her how the duke
his fader should mary hi^ whereof he was sore displesed for the love of her. ca.
ix, fol. v. How yt Arthur and Hector his cousin germayne were made knights for
the love of Arthur, who than did ensure Pe^ron daughter to the ladi luke of
ostrige, and of ye great tournai yt was there done at nau^tes for the love of
arthur. ca. x. folio.v. How that Arthur wedded fair Perron daughter to the
lady Luke of ostryge. And of the protestacyon that he made before all the
barony. ca. xi. fol. vii. How this lady Luke of ostryge sent for Iehannet and
caused her secretlye the first night to lie with arthur because yt perro^ was no
maid, to thentente that arthur should not perceive it ca. xii. fo. vii. How yt
Iehannet who was a bed with arthur in the stead of his wife Perro^, and or she
would suffer him to touch her she demanded her endowrie. ca. xiii. fo. ix. How
that arthur Hector, and Gouernar went erly in the morninge to se Ieha^net at
the stange, who showed unto ar^hur all the treason of his wife, and how that
she had layne with him all that night instead of Perron, whereof he meruayled
greatly^ cap. xiiii. fol. eodem How ye Gouernar vaynquisshed in battle sir
Au^sel caused hi^ to make knowledge of this treason and co^fe^sed how yt he

How arthur demanded license of his father and mother to go play him out of his

prowess. cap* xvi fol. xii. How the mighty king of Soroloys called Eme^dus
held open court in his realm, where as was four puyssau^te kings, who were
al his subgectes, and there ye shall here of things right meruaylo^s.
capitulo.xvii. folio xiiii (...) ^^scrypcyon of the facyon and sytuacy^^ of the

of his arms and two rybbes in his sides. capitulo.xxx. fol. xxxi. H^w that

capitulo.lvii. folio.xx. How on the next morning the vylayn brought Arthur to

The first Chapyter makes mencyon of the birth of the noble knight Arthur
son and heir to the duke of Brytayne. Capitulo..1.


AFter the death of good king Arthur who was right noble and gentle,
specially in cherys^hynge and enhaunsynge of nobylnesse, and mayntaynyng of the
chyualrous knights of the world. As was Gawyn and Lancelotte and many other
noble kng^htes as it is more plainly contained in diverse ancient chronicles. It
is of troth that in tho days in Brytayne there was a duke right prudente and
above all other right virtuous, rich and puyssaunte both of hauyour and
friends, who was come and extraughte of the noble high lygnage of the valyau^t
knight lau^celot du lake who was in his days of right hight and noble prowess
as it is more at large comprised in the books making mencyon of his chyualrye.
This Duke had to name Johan and was so endued with sappence yt the king who as
than governed all France loved and honored him above all other in so much
it was said where so ever he went behold yonder is the wise man of britain,
he was sworn of the kings preuye and streayte counsel so that the king was
only governed by his noble advise because of the great ^^ou the and
steadfastness yt was ever found in him, this duke hadd a right noble lady to
his wife of good and holy life who was daughter to the earl of Leycester in
England, and they loved together right fervently by cordyall love al their
life, and in accomplyshing between them the works of marriage ordained by
nature fynaltye it pleased the good Lord to send them a fair son, who in
the remembrance of good king Arthur and of his hye renown was named Arthur.
This child was goodly and of full great beauty For afterward he grew to be the
most fair creature that than was found in all crystendome and the dukes and
duches loved him so well that they intended to nothing but all only to the
prouffyte of their child, and specially to enhaunce his honor and rych^sse.

How the duke of brytayne delivered his son Arthur to the governance of a
prudent knight named sir Gouernar who did ensign him in all goodlye manners
and deeds of arms, so that afterward there was non like unto him. Ca. ii.
ANd wha^ this child Arthur was nine year of age than the Duke his fader
delivered him to be kept under the governance of a noble and a gentyl master
named Gouernar who was right prudent, puyssau^t and hardy, virtuous ^ vygorous
of body and well proved, who among other things did teach this noble
child Arthur the play of the chesse and tables so yt non was in co^ninge like
unto him. And wha^ he was of.xx. year than his master taught him the man^re of
skyrmyshe so that wtin a little season there was none able to be compared with him.
Thus amended this child from day to day and grew so goodly yt in all the
world there was none seen like him nether so fayre^ so gracyous ne so cou
reyse in so much yt the king of France desired ofte^tymes yt he should have
be noryshed and brought up with his one children. How be it ye duchess his
mother could in no wise suffer it ne scant to let him be out of her presence
never a day she loved him so enterly. So long this child soiourned with his
mother yt it was gretlye noyful to his heart, in so much that thereby he became
right pensyfe ^ sore troubled in his mind. So that gouernar his master
demanded of hi^ what was the cause of his sorrow. In good faith master said
Arthur this long soiorning and abiding at home greatly noyeth me, for I would
gladly go and play me in yo^der fair forest. And to hunt and chase after a
great heart. For it has been now a great season sithe I went any where forth.
Se^ t^ynly said gouerner fair Arthur it pleases me right well your noble
mi^d. There go to my ford pour fader and desire his lyce^ce that ye may go
chase in ye forest. Th^n arthur went forth to y^ duk his fader and demanded of
him license wha^ the duke hard this tydyng and will of his son he had great joy
and right sweet did grant him his request and commanded and desired Gouernar
that he should take good head to him and not suffer him to ^enne ne to follow to
fast after his dysport. Gouernar answered that he would take good head to him.
Than arthur caused ye hu^ters to be warned and to make ready his greyhou^des,
hounds and other raches for he wo^de go the next day be times to chase in
the forest. And the next morning Arthur and Gouernar mounted on their horses
with great Joy and.x. other gentylmen to keep them company. And arthur was
mounted on a great courser his hat hanging on his back by a lace of sylke,
his bonet on his head and the hunters went before ledinge his greyhoundes and
hounds. Thus they ride forth toward the forest in great joy.

How arthur found in the forest a noble lady without socour, and with her a fair
young maid, her daughter named Iehannet before a little lodge the which they
had made of ye branches of the trees, and how that arthur was amorus of the
said Iehannet. Cap. iii.
IN this time there was in the real me of desert a knight of great power and
right rich of hauiour and friends, and he was Lord of a castle called the
toure. This knight was named Vyciers and was of such virtue that he douted
nothi^ge.x. knights armed, and was of so valiant courage that sin the time that
he could first bear arms he was never but there as he knew where as the fayte
of arms were occupied, and employed himself ever in iustes and tornayes and
in deeds of arms and did so to be allowed yt there was no speki^ge of him but
that he was the noblest knight of the world, but finally he led so his life
that he spe^ded and wastest his goods so largely to the^te^r to get him laud
and praise that at the end he became thereby very port and tha^ was faint to
fell and to make shyfte of all y^ he had both of his own and of the good lady
his wife. And so dyed in great pouerte. And when he was buried such persons
as he was detter unto, took all the lands and goods that perteyned other to
him or to the lady his wife, so y^ there by the good lady his wife fled and
departed pryuely out of ye country, so y^ non of her friends wyste where she
was become, for she thought she had rather to live poorly in a strange
country far fro her fre^des and aqueyntaunce tha^ to endure pouerte in her
own country where she had been nobly brought up in before. So this lady went
and her daughter with her, who was of the age of.xiiii year right beautefull,
how be it she was porely arrayed and had to name I^hannet. And they trauayled so
long by their Journeys y^ by adventure they came in to the forest where Arthur
and Gouernar were used to chase and to hunte. And in a desolate place of the
forest far from any hye way there these two ladies did rest them and made
them a lodge to abide in of boughs and of such things as they could get
Thus they continued the space of a month. And this lady went eueri day right
porely to the next vylage for to get suthe things as she and her daughter
neded. And so it fortuned yt ^he same day y^ Arthur and gouernar departed fro
the court of his fader and was entered into the said foreste anon his hounds
had found a great heart, And a noble knight yt was in his company named the
lord Olyuer of I^y^c followed after this heart on a great courser and all the
other hu^ters after him. And this young Arthur began to follow after, how be it
Gou^r^ar took head y^ he should not follow to fast^, so y^ this said lord
Olyuer and ^ll other were past f^rth by him and were gone so far into the
thick of ye foreste y^ Arthur and Gouernar had clean lost both sight and
heringe of the^ and of their hou^des. And so by ges they followed fair and
esyly after, so long they followed y^ by adventure they came to the same place
where as the lodge was made for the lady and her daughter, who were both the
same time sitting without the lodge door. And as soon as Arthur saw them he
lyghted down of his horse and Gouernar with him. And wha^ this lady saw Arthur
she was greatly abashed for she thought well y^ he should be some great man and
there with she rose and Arthur right swetely saluted her. And the lady in like
wise again to him. And at y^ time it was about three of the clock. And when
the lady saw Arthur and Gouernar dyscende from their horses, she remembered
the state of her fader and of other ge^^^lmen y^ she had seen before in her
own country where as she had be norysshed up u^ whereof her heart was gretely
ashamed and troubled. Than Arthur took her by the hand and her mother also and
set them do^ne all together. Than Arthur demanded of the young maid and said
fair sweet damoysell what is your name. As our lord help me sir I am called
Iehannet, Ieha^ne^ good love where were ye borne certain sir I was not born in
this country. Than her mother said sir truly my daughter says sothe, for
truly she was borne in the lo^d of desarte in a castle called the tour. Truly
said Arthur to whom was she daughter. As God help me sir to a knight right
strong and puyssau^t who in his time loved ever deeds of arms and was
acque^ted with many noble men How be it his fortune was such or he dyed yt he
lost away and wasted both his lands and goods and mine that was his poor
wife. And were brought so far under that little or nothing was left us. And
after his death such persons as he owed any thing to, and peradventure some
other yt he owed nothing to. They were tha^ so importune on me that I was feign
to sell al yt I had. And when I saw that I was so far brought under and yt I
had nothing left me whereby to live The occasion thereof caused me to steal
away by night* for I thought I had lever go like a poor woman a beggynge in a
strange country tha^ there where I was lady and governor. And therewith right
pyteously she wept and said a gentyl^ knight now am I come in to this country
a lonely accompanied with this yo^g maid my dear daughter, who was wo^t be
brought up in fair places and rich halles and chambres, and to lie in the bed
incorteyned with sylke. And now it be ho^eth her to lie on the moss in this
lodge covered with grene boughs. Than Arthur answered and said a fair lady
why did not ye require your friends to help and socour you in your necessite
At least to give you mete and drink and clothing. In my mi^d that had be more
honorable for you tha^ thus desolate to come in to this strange cou^trye. As
god help me sir said this lady pore folks has but few friends, how be it I
ought to have many, but between the rich and the poor there wants friends,
for the rich makes his friends of his money and the pore is ever put out in
every place. And as to me sorrowful creature who has been a great lady and
much honored and have had much people under my obeysau^ce, thought great
shame to require any creature in my own cu^tre to help or soccoure me. And
specially for this young maid my daughter, she is come of goodly lygnage. Alas
as for me I am old and always she has served me right well, and now she is
like with me to lose her time, and there with she began again to weep. And when
Ieha^net saw her mother so weep she could not abstain her self from weeping
tenderly. And when Arthur saw them so full of sorrow, he had great pity and
said to the lady. My right dear lady weep ye no more but set your heart in
rest for fro he^sforth I will be in the stead of your old lord, and in all
good honor to lu^e and cherish you to the best of my power. And all this
while Ieha^net made still great la^entaco^. So there Arthur took the young
maid in his arms, and right swetely said. My right dear ^adye and love
abandon your heart to joy and leave this sorrow for as god be my socoure I
shall cause you have more honor and wealth than as yet eu^rcame to you, for I
am and shall be your own good loue^ and will take you in to my hands to
deliver you fro all pouertye, faithfully assuryng you to keep the honor of you
and of your body as much as your own p^opre brother would or might do.

How Arthur caused to be delivered to Ieha^net and her mother y^ revenues yt
belonged to the stang or ponde of the forest whereby there stood a fair goodly
place of pleasure, and afterward Arthur, did often tym^s resort thither to
pass the time with them. Capit. iiii.
IN this season yt Arthur had this co^munycacio^ with these ladies, there came to
the^ the master forester named Pyere who was also receyuer the revenues of
the forest and he had al ye day so^ghte his master Arthur and by adventure
there he found him talking with these ladies, And inco^tynent yt Arthur saw hi^
he called him by his name and demaundyd of hi^ if he had received at yt
mawdeleyn tide ye revenues of the forest, and Piers answered and said, sir I
have already at your commandment to the some of. five. C. pound, well quod
Arthur I command the incontynente to deliver it to this lady and to her
daughter. Also the manner place pertaining to the stang of this forest wherein
thou have dwelt to this time. It was so that in this sta^ge or water the wild
beasts of the foreste did ever thither resort to drink. and Ioynynge to this
water there were houses and manners the which the duke had given to arthur his
son to play hi^ in the forest, and this pyers was keeper thereof to Arthurs
behoue. Than said Arthur to Pyers I deliver to y^ these.ii. ladies. And I
charge the y^ truly y^ keep and honor them and bring them to my manner and to
deliver to them such as is apertenau^te to so goood by ladies as they be. And
as such a man as I am have taken into my hands and keeping. Therefore keep the^
well and truly. For by the faith yt I owe to my lord my fader if I know y^ you
entende or ymagen against this lady or her daughter any dyspleasure. I shall
cause the to suffer foul death. And I warn the look yt they lack no thing.
Sir said Pyers I trust I shall so demane me yt both you and they shall be with me
content. And so wha^ Arthur had been there a great season, he took his leave
there of this lady and of her daughter. So Pyers did conduyte them to the said
manner and bought for them abylementes and Iewelles, mete and drink of the best
yt could be gotten, and all other things yt was co^uenyent for noble ladys to
have. And garnysshed every office in ye house with plate of silver and with all
other necessary things. And when Arthur and Gouernar were departed fro these
ladies they rode after the tracke of sir Olyuer of Iryac and his company, and
at the last they mete together far in the forest in a great deep valey where
as sir Olyuer had killed three great hearts, and was brekynge of them. And
therewith Arthur came to him and laughed right swetely. Than resorted other of
the hunters fro all parties. And so there Arthur commanded a servant
belonging to the said Pyers to take one of these hearts and to bear it fro him
to the said lady and to her daughter. And the second Arthur did give to an
abbotte that was come to them by adventure. And the third he commanded that
it should be conveyed to the duke his fader, who had great joy thereof.

How within.viii. days after Arthur and Gouernar went to the stange to se the
lady and Iehannet her daughter, Capitulo..v.
THe eight day after that Arthur was come fro the foreste he rose erly in a
fair morninge and said to gouernar, friend let us go leap upon our horses
and goo se our damoysell in the forest we two alone, gladly sir said Gouernar.
So Arthur took a sparhawke on his hand, and Gouernar a gerfawcon. And Arthur
aparayled him self all in grene silk, and his hatte auayled with a fresshe
chaplet of flowers on his head. And they rode so long that by the son
rysynge they came to the stang and found the lady and Iehannet ready aparayled
right nobly. For Pyers the forester had purueyed them of all things necessary
to such ladies. And as than Iehannet had dronken good wynes and taken her
sustenaunce of good metes, and had forgote^ all her sorrow. Whereby her beauty
was newly renewed. And when Arthur saw her, she pleased him much better tha^
she did when he saw her first. And so took her by the fair hand and set
them down together a part. And in the mean season the lady her mother and
Gouernar were talking together. And the morning was very fair and clear. And
the earth all bedewed with clear silver drops. An^ the byrddes sange
m^lodiously on every branch so that these.ii. young lusty lovers greatly
reioysed, and had great myrthe in their hearts because of the sweet season as
it was metely for such young people to play and to laughe. And they loved
together with good heart without thinkinge of vylany or shame each to other.
Than Arthur said to her al laughyng. My sweet damoysell have ye any manner of
lover. And half smili^g and beholdynge Arthur right swetely she answered, by
the faith that I owe to you my owen dear lord, I have one right fair and
gracyous. And where is he my sweet Iehannet. By my faith ^yr he is of a country
whereof he is lord. And fair love how is he called, sir you not dyspleased,
this that I have said is suffycyent at this present teme. How be it sir I
would ye knew that king Arthur was a noble knight and of great virtue And sir I
would my lover were so good if he be not better all ready. But one thing sir I
assure you he resembles more to you than to any other under the son living,
both going, and in coming of body and all other things that one person
may be lykened to an other. My own sweet and fair damoysell said Arthur I
would feign se him. And by the faith that ye ow to me if it be to you no vylony
I pray you show him to me and I promise you faithfully I shall love and
cherysshe. him right derely. And for the love of you if yt he will he shall be
one of my house, if he be no greater of lygnage ne of richesse than I am. My
^ight dear lord said this damoysel humbly I thank you how be it he is no
grea^ter gentylman than ye be, but he thinks well to have as great honor and
friends as ye have, but as now ye may not se him* but it may well be that here
after ye shall have knowledge of him. And so thus they comoned together of many
things till it was time that Arthur should return to the court, for as than
it was about pryme. Than Arthur took his leave of the lady and of Iehannet. And
so he and gouernar mounted on their horses and rode forth always deuisyng of
the manner of this damoysell Iehannet. And at the last Arthur said. Master how
say you by the swetnesse of our damoysell and of the frenes of her heart, and
how sagely and gracyo^slye she answers to every demand, remembrynge also
her gentle manner and noble countenance, her beawtefull facyon of body and of
vysage. As god help me master all these things and many other that saemeth
of virtue to be in her, causes that I love her hyrtely. Sir said Gouernar as
God help me all that ye say is of troth, how be it mine own dear lord take
good head to your honor and remember how great a lord ye be, both of lygnage,
honor and of friends. And think how that she is but a poor gentylwoman as
to your knowledge. And if ye do her any vylony to her body, as in taking from
her that he can not render again, sir it were t^ you a great sin. And ye
ought therein to be more blamed than a another means person. Master said
arthur I pray to god never to help me if I think to go about to dysshonoure
her, but I will love her and keep her honor faithfully in like case as she
were mine owen proper sister without ever desyringe onye velany to her body. So
they rode forth talkyng til they came to the court, and than went to dinner
for it was by that time nere upon two of the clock.

How that the duke and duchess took counsel to mary their sone arthur and how
they sent their steward to the lady Luke of ostrige for to demand her
daughter for Arthur. Cap. vi
IN this wise Arthur soiurned a great long space so yt there was no we^e but
that twyse or thri^e he and Gouernar would ride to the stange with out any
other company. And it fortuned one day he tarried there longer tha^ he was a
customed to do, wherefore he was sought all about by the commandment of the
duke his father how be it no tydinges could be herd of him but that he and
Gouernar were gone togider to sport them, but no man wyste whyther. And than
the duchess said to the duke, sir I wot not what means that our soon thus
goth forth so pryuely every day and no man can tell whyther, for he takes none
with him but Gouernar^ veraylye I doubt me of our child least that he should
set his heart and love on some person whereby we should have any velony, sir he
is now of years sufficient to perc^iue and to know the fair perteyning to love
wherefore I would he were nobly married for it is time, he is.xxii. years of age.
Madame quod the duke ye have right wisely said. And I acorde well thereto, but
to whom think ye best it were to give him in marriage. Sir said the lady in
my mind it were well doon^ that we should demand the fair Perron of os^ryge,
and I trust my lady Luke her mother will be thereof right glad, verily madame said
the duke I have hard say that this lady Perron has not wyselye demeaned her
self* but has had great blame for her nyse keeping company w a knight of her
country. And I would for no good yt we should demand such a person as has
deserved blame. A sir said the lady believe not ye the reports of them that
lusts to say y^, for as god help me she is slaundred wrongfully. for I am
sure the eis not a better maid living, wherefore they are in great sin that
reports ot^erwyse of her. Dame said the duke if it be so I am right joyful.
Than let us send thither in all have Than was called to them sir Olyuer yt was
senesshall. And the duke said to him, sir Olyuer I will ye go to ost^yge to my
lady Luke and desire of her in my b^ha^e Pe^ron her daughter to be given in
matrymony to a^thur my sone. T^a^ sir Olyuer prepayred him to ride forth
And.x. other knights in his company. and so departed and rode forth so long
that the wednesdaye after Mawdeleyntyde they came to ostryge. And when sir
Oliver was in the great hall where as the lady Luke was acompanyed with many
great barons ladies and damoysels. He did right reverently salute her and all
the other lords and barons as a messenger sent fro the duke and duchess of
Britayne. And this lady Luke right honorably did receive him and all his
company. And demanded what was the cause and the occasyon of their coming.

How the senesshall demanded the daughter of ostryge for arthur of Brytayne,
the which request with great Joy was granted him. Cap. vii.
THan sir Olyuer began his proposicion and said. Right hye and myg^ty
princes. My lord and lady of brytayne has se^d us hither to publishe unto
you their ententes for they are right desirous to have love and affinity with
you as it well appears, for they have hard such bruce and fame of my lad^
Per^o^ your daughter. Wherefore they have sent me hither to your presence to
require you in their behalf to give your daughter perron in marriage to arthur
their sone, who is right gentyl, noble and valiant. Madame this is the effect
of our request. In the name of god said the lady luke humbly I thank the duke
your lord yt it will please him to have with us acquentaunce, whereof I have
right great Joy. And wi^h a good heart I give freely to him my daughter Perron
to be all holly at his comau^deme^t Madame said Oliver this deed ought greatly
to be thanked. And how say you fair lady perron, do you acorde to this
marriage. Sir said Perron I shall ever fulfill the pleasure of my lady my mother.
Certainly fair lady than do you wisely for I ensure you ye shall be coupled
to him yt is both fair and goodly. Than this ladi luke and her daughter did
give to sir Oliver and to his company many noble Jewels and other things.
And their apoyntment was to be at nauntes within.viii. days of the middell of
the next August.

How yt arthur was sore dyspleased for yt his father would mayr hi^ to ye
daughter of ostryge because it was said she was of ill governance. Ca. viii.
THan the senesshal took le^e of the lady Luke and of the fair Perron and

and the duchess with hi^ And arthur and Gouernar were playing at the chesse,

right humblye saluted them and thanked them greatly for the great love and

ap^^ayled to be given to Ar^hur about the middell of August next insuyng. And
wha^ Arthur herd that his fader would mary him he stepped forth and left his

said the duke right nobly. And good fader unto whom will ye give me, Fair
sone unto the gentil perron of ostryge. What sir as it is noysed she has
trespased with a another knight^ set ye so little by me that ye will now give me
perro^ who is of ill name and fame. Certainly it is not your worship ne honor
so to do nor to none of my friends. Therefore in no manner of wise I will take

is said by this lad^ it is great sin to say such things as cannot be proved
for I am in certain that she is a clean maiden. And therefore we will that ye
shall have her or else ye shall greatly dysplease my lord your father and me also*
well madame said Arthur since that it behooves me to take her and that it is your
pleasure y^^ I so do I am content, how be it if she be of such conditions as
is said of her I shall never love her. Than said gouernar to the duke, sir ye
will that Arthur shall have this damoisell. Nevertheless pleases you sir to

if that she did never such trespass tha^ let arthur keep her as he ought to do

such things are lightly done so covertly that it is hard to know, sir said
Gouernar let it be inquired wisely of such as to presume should know of the
matter. Also let the damoysell her self be wisely examyned, and if she be good
she will keep her self, if she be otherwise perauenture it will be espied. I
am content with this said arthur. And for that time they left their commi^g of
that matter. Than the duke sent out his commandments to all his barons,

marye him to the fair Perron of ostryge. The duke also did write to the earl

of Aniou who was nere of kin to the duke^ and also to the archebysshop of
^ou^s desyringe them to be at n^untes at the said day.

How that arthur went to se Iehannet and declared to her how ye duke his

Arthur.


THa^ arthur and gouernar took their horses and rode to the strange in the

How that Arthur and Hector his cosyn germayne were made knights for the love

ANd when all these noble people were ass^bled together the duke and duch^sse

How that Arthur wedded fair Perron daughter to the lady Luke of ostryge. And
of the protestacion that he made before all the barony. Capitulo. xi.


NOw shows the history how yt wha^ arthur, Hector and Gouernar were d^parted
from Iehannet they came to the court. And by that time were all lords
knights and al other risen fro their rest. And the archebyshop of toures was
ready to sing mass and solempny se the matrymony. And than the duke and the
duchess and all the other lords, knights ladies and damoysels did convey

people and in open audyence Arthur said. I will that it be known yt if ever I
find true such words as I have hero say of this lady thought I were
wedded to her a houdred thousand times yet I will leave and utterly forsake
her. And on that condycio^ her I am now content to take her to my wife and
none other wise. And thereto was well acorded her mother and all other of their
friends. And so with great solemnyte they we^e wedded together, and great was
the feast add Joy that than was made in all the cite, ladies damoyselles did
dance and made gret^ joy and myrthe and made chaplettes and tokens and did
give them to lords and knights in the sign of love.

How this lady Luke of os^ryge sent ^or Iehannet and caused her secretly the
first night to lie with Arthur because y^ Perron was no maid, to the ^ntente
yt Arthur should not perceive it. Ca. xii.
WE must know how that dame Luke during all this season that this great Joy
and mirth was made, she was in great thought in her heart because she knew well
yt her daughter. Perron was no maid, therefore she doubted greatly to have
vylonye.

And therefore she wyste not what was best for her to do. So at the last she
called to her one of her own knights in whom she trusted best in all her
business. And than she showed unto him all the demenoure of Perron, and
desired him to give her in that behalf the best counsel yt he knew, for
she saw well how that arthur would feign find some cause by her to the
^ntente that he might be departed fro her company. For sir quod she if Arthur
find that she be no maid, than I doubt me of vy^any. Therefore I require you
for gods love to counsel me in this case. Than this knight who had to name
sir Aunsell, answered and said, madame sith it is thus the case must be
suffered as easily as it may be. For when the deed is done than it is time to
take counsel both sage and secret. I shall tell you what we shall do, here is
by dwelling at the stange in the forest a poor damoysell right fair and
young, who has a mother a right good ancient lady. And I think verily she be
a good maid. Send unto her mother part of your silver and gold, an^ promise
to do for her many other things so that she will ^ende you her daughter for
this first night to lie with arthur t^ll mydnyght be paste. And I think
verily ye shall have her if she be wisely entreted and secretly. And than if ye
have her wha^ Perron should be laid in the bed she shall be in her stead till
that arthur be a sleep and than she shall rise. And so than Perron shall lie
down by arthur. A sir said the lady for gods sake think on to bring ^his
matter about. Take my charyot and five hundred pounds of gold and bear it
unto her mother and show her how I shall give her large lo^des and rentes, and
shall mary her daughter right hyghly so that I may have her this night. So
tha^ incon^inent this knight clepte on his horse, and took with him the gold
and the cha^yot and caused it to be covered and robe unto the stange where as
he found this fair lady and her daughter, and did salute them right swetely
and drew them aparte, and said to the lady. M^dame I am come hither to you
fro my lady Luke of ostryge, who right ^enderly sends gretynge unto you. As
she that fro he^sforth will be your enspecyall lover and friend And above all
other will love and honor you. And in the sign of love she has sent you
five hondreth pounds of gold. And ferthermore promyseth you to give you
great lands and goods and to mary right hyely Ieha^net your daughter, so
that ye will do her that bounte and pleasure now at this time as to send your
daughter to her to the entente to lie this first night with Arthur of Brytayne

point as she would she were for ^^e has trespaced with another knight
Therefore good lady I humbly require you for to be her special lover and friend

their pain to cover and to hyde such matters. And also every woman to help

vylonye for she does it to hyde her own dyshonoure. Truly dought^r quod the
lady, the mother yt demeneth not wisely her child is to be blamed, and if my
lady Luke have not kept this lady Perron her daughter as curyouslye and as

folly and danger, let her take it a worth and thank no body but her self.
Madame said Iehannet it is a hard thing to overcome youth, for if this lady

love by whom she was overcome. For to serur her floryshyng yougth. For god she
loved and was loved again, remember also the great case wherein she has all

and love. Madame if I trepas I are mercy, for by the faith yt I ow to you I

How arthur demanded license of his fader and mother to go play him out of his

hands, and finally I cast up mine eyes alofte, and on my right hand me thought
I saw the richeste pauilion pyghte that ever was seen, and in the hight of
this pauylyon was an egle of gold the richest and the fayreste that could be
devised and properly me thought I saw this egle come down and light on my
bosom and showed me so great sign of love that it pleased me so much that I
coudle not be satysfyed with beholdynge thereof, and me thought it flykered about
me with her wings in the sign of great love, and at the last me thought I
saw where came to me ward a great griffon foul and horrible and he brought
with him a great multitude of serpents: wherwt all the earth about me was
covered, and me thought they would have taken fro me mine egle who was right
ferde and covered her ever by me and looked on me swetely. In manner as though
she would have said arthur keep me. And than me thought I took my sword in
my hand and so fought with this gryffon and al these serpents, by whom me
thought I suffered much pain in great peril, but at the last me thought
there came a turtyll to help me and brought with her many douues. And out of
an other part I saw where came a sparhawke accompanied with many faucons. And
all these did me such socoure that we slew yt gryffon and all the other
serpents. And sodaynely than me thought that the egle and y^ turtyll and I
were in a hye toure, and both you Hector, and Gouernar with me. And to us me
thought came people without nombre and me thought there was a lion and four
great leopardes. And all they did enclyne them self to me ward and did
me great honor. And they were al crowned with gold and me thought they gave the
egle freely to me, And she pleased me so well that I would never have departed
by my will fro her company. And ever sith I woke my heart and love has been so
set on ye egle that I can not draw my heart fro her. For I love her so entyerly
y^ aalonge as I live I shall never cease to travel and labor till I have
found her And this is the very cause wherefore I am departed out of mine own
country. Uer^ly sir said Gouernar this be^okeneth ye great honor shall come
to you, for sir ye know well the lion, who as ye thought did give you the egle
is a be tyail. For the lion is king of all beestes. And the egle is king of
all fowls. So the sygnyfycacyon thereof is that a king shall give you a
queen, how be it great pain shall ye first suffer. And the griffo^ yt would
have taken fro you your egle, betokens some great man y^ would have her that
shall be given to you. Therefore it shall behoue you to conquer her with the
sword, and sir I Gouernar your servant am here yt never shall fail you while
I live, no more shall I fair cosyn said Hector by the faith that I awe unto my
lor^e my father. Friends said Arthur I heartily thank you. And so they rode
forth on their way. And because ye shall understand the sygnyfycacyon of the
egle and the lion. Therefore we shall leave for a season spekyng of arthur and
his company rydyng on their Journey, and ye shall hear of this egle till time
shall be that we return again to Arthur.

How the mighty king of Sorolois called Emendus held open court in his

ye shall here of things meruaylous. Capitulo..xvii.


IN the season that arthur thus rode as ye have herd here before there was in
the realm of Soroloys a king, the which realm is in Ind the more. Joining to
the great see called Betee. And also to the read see between Mesopotanye and
perse. This king had to name Emendus, right puyssaunt of hauydur and friends.
And he had under him four kings mighty and puyssaunt, who were under his

orquany, the which is on the side of babylon, the which realm extends to the
read see, and this land was full of gyauntes. The second was king of the
realm of Mormall the which is in the land of Sodom and gomorre, and it
extends to the lord Ioynynge to the dead see. And this king might well
bring in batayl better tha^ a ho^dred.M. fighting men. The third has the
governance of the realm of Valefounde, a very obscure and dark land and the
people thereof as black as sote, and it exte^deth into the oryent where as the
son ryseth, the which people were greatly doubted in battle or war, for
they were without pity. And did eat raw flesh like dogs. The fourth

the land of Femene. These.iiii. kings were subjects to the mighty king of
Doroloys Emendus. who had to w^se a noble lady named Fenyce by the reason of
the country yt she was borne in For it was named fenyx because in that coun^ree
bredde a bird yt was called fenyx. And in all the world there is never but
one, and as it is said when she is old and ancient there she makes her
neste of dry thorns on the heyghte of an hye mountain as nere the son as
she can so y^ by the hete of the son the nest quickens and flameth on fire,
and the she in bre^neth herself, and of her ashes there is another fenyx
^ngendred. This said lady Fenyce wife to king Emendus was queen by
enherytaunce of the clear toure the which was a noble rich cite. And by
great force she had subdued ^he city of co^meyne and of constantinople of
cornite of Macedonye, of Phesale, of Bo^me and of all the country of denmarche.
She was a right hye and a mighty pryncesse, and right good and virtuous, so yt
it was hard than to have found any lady comperable to her. And so it
fortyned in the fresh merry month of may, as at the feast of pentecost ye

feast was great, and the court full of people And the first day of this feast
the king Emendus was in his palace lenyng on a rod of gold yt he held in
his hand and about him stood these four kings and his.vii. perres accompanied
also with the hye and mighty duke of Alatre and.xxiiii earls. And his noble
queen Fenyce satte by him great with child, and nere to her time of
delyueraunce. And the king of orguany beheld her well, who was her ne^e cosyn
and said. Madam^ me think it should be metelye for your grace fro hensforth
to draw to the place where as the king will y^ ye shall take your chamber,
for I think your time approaches on fast. In deed fair cosyn said the queen
ye say right truly, how be it I know not as yet where as my lord will I
shall lie. And thereto the king answered and said. In deed as yet I am not
determined in what place she shall lie in. Than said the king of Mormall, who
was a sage prince, sir I will counsel you let the queen lie at the port
Noyr, and when she is delivered let the child be borne to the hill of
adventures. And sir if ye do thus I think ye shall do wisely. By my faith quod
the king of Ualefounde I wo^e not what to say in this matter whether it were
better to bear the child thither or not, for this is your first child. And
it is hard to tell what destynye ^he child shall be of, if it shall be good
than were it well ^one yt it were borne thither But peradventure ye adventures
of this child may be such that it were better they were hid and kept
secret than to be openly known. For in adventure lies often times as well
ill as good. Well quod the king Emendus. Madame I will that ye go to the port
Noyre And when that ye be delivered I will that the child be borne up to the
mount perylons, there to know what destyny that the child shall be of.

The dyscrypcion of the facyon and sytuacyon of the mount perylous the which

IN this mou^te perylous there was a castle named the port Noyre, This

How that the daughter of the mighty king Ga^^nd^s, and of ^e^ice his queen
was destyned over the fountain in the herber of the mount peril^ous by four

most fairest creature than of all the world. Cap. xx.


THan this queen Proserpyne began first and said. I perceive well here is the
daughter of our dear fre^des the king Emendus whom he has sent hither to us
with great triumph therefore it is good reason that we do him some good and
pleasure. Madam said the other three queen's begin you. And we shall follow,
certainly said she with a right good will. First I will yt this child be named
Florence, and that she shall be flower of beauty of all other c^eatures as
long as ever she shall live and properly I will she shall resemble to me both in
face, in body, in countenance in goinge, and coming. And in all other
things so like* that whosoever se us both together shall not consider nor
dyscerne the one fro the other. And also to her I give this my castle of the
port Noyr, and my pauylyon with ^he Image holding the Chaplet. And also my
why^e shield and sword. And therewith she held her peace. And than the second
queen said. Madame sith that ye have made he^ to be fair with out co^paryson. I
will also that she shall be gracious and amyable. well quod the third queen sith
I see that she shall be exceeding fair and gracious without comparison. And
madame seen she shall have your semblaunt and your shield and sword. I will
that the best knight of the world shall have her marriage. And I will that he
shall bear the white sheld and the sword, and that they shall help none other
creature but alonely him. And I will that he shall achyeue the adventures of
this castle, and shall put to death Malegra^e the Monstour, and to him I give
the sheelde and the sword and the chaplet yt the image holds in the
pauyl^on. And also I will that he shall have this maid Florence in marriage.
Than the fourth queen said, well sister sith ye have given this maid to the
best knight of the world. I will tha^ that if any other be so bold to take
her, that incontinent he shall die or he have power to touch her. And therewith
all these queen's rose and went there ways. And than the queen of Ismaelite
and the king of Orqueny and the archebysshop took the ch^^de and bare it to her
mother and there openly recounted to her all yt they had hard and seen of

gave her to name Florence. And than the queen of Ismaelite and the king of
Orquenye held her on the founte^ the which child was kept up with four
norses. And she grew and amended daily so that she was toward to be fairest
creature of ye world And when the queen was pu^ified she went to the city of
Sabba where as the king Emendus was accompanied with his kings, and the seven
peers of his realm. And this was at all halowentyde where as he kept a great
open court. And when the queen was come the king met her with great triumph.

How yt the queen Fenice mother to florence died, and how she made her testament

THis queen Fenice loved greatly her daughter Florence, who was the most
fairest creature that as than could be found in all the world. For there was
none that ever saw her, but incontinent they were rauysshed with her persaunt
b^au^^. And the queen her mother kept her so derely that there were but few men
that had any sight of her, for y^ king her own father saw her not so often as
he would have done. In this manner she was kept till she was.xviii. year of age.
Than it fortuned on a season that this king Emendus held open court at
Pantopone. And to him were come al his other kings and noble baronage at which
time the queen his wife was right sore dyseased of the fever and every day
inpayred more and more, and so the second day of this feast this noble queen
Fenyce than as she lay in her bed she saw where as her daughter Florence stood
sore weeping before her beds side where with she began to make a pitefull
lamentacion and said. A dear daughter Florence I have kept and cherished you

n^des leave you. And I fer^ me yt after my death ye shall have need of me. And
therewith she sent for the king Emendus her husband, and for other four
kings, and for all the seven peers of the realms. And when they were a^ come
into her presence she said to the king Emendus her husband. Right dear lord
I am sure it is not out of your remembrance the desteny of our daughter
Florence, therefore sir now in my last days I humbly require you that ye ^il
keep and up hold the promise and other as ye have made in that behalf
heretofore to the which ye are bound to by your seal and wrytinge. And
suffer her never to be given to other lord in marriage but to him that she is
predystinate unto. In the name of god quod the king madame I faithfully assure
you to uphold all that I have promised well than to you syrs quod the queen ^o

archebysshop. Fair lords I leave in your kepinge my de^e daughter Florence
praying you to keep her well and truly. For sir bishop she is your own ^ese.
And to you sir king of orqueny she is cosyn and goddoughter, therefore ye ought
to take good head to her. And to you my own de^e lord and husband and to all

that was there present. Than Florence step p^d forth all in a rage and piteosly

desolate creature. And therewith she would have lepte and ^yssed the dead corse

that no body took head of the woeful Florence, til at the last the archebysshop

in every church began to sound. And every creature made great sorrow for the
death of the queen. And the king caused her bodi to kept above the ground.ix.
days for to abide the barons and knights of the realm of blaunche toure for

How that the queen Fenice mother to Florence was nobly entiered. Cap. xxiii
About the end of.xx. days their came a knight to king Emendus fro
the emperor of Inde the more. who had heard tidinges how that the queen Fenice
was departed this transitory life, and he desired the king to prolonge four
days longer the enterme^t of the queen, for he sent word that he would be
with him by that season where of king Emendus was very glad that so hie a
person as the Emperor was would take on him for to be at the beryenge of the
queen his wife. And when the day came of his coming he was received fulright
and honourabl^ and tha^ the service was ministered to the dead body full right
hi^ and solemp^ely and so she was laid in the cathidral chirch of all the
city. And this Emperor abode there still a great space afterward wy^h the
king to the entente to put him of his great sorrow. And all other kings
earls and barons deparparted every man into his own country. And also the
archebisshop returned to cornite. And so took his leave of the king his brother,
and led with him Florence his nese. And also Florence took leave of the king her
fader and of the Emperor who was as than all bedewed with we^ping, and not
araied as perteined to her estate, but after the manner of a sorrowful morner.
How be it in such state as she was in, she was of great beauty whereby this
Emperor was stricken with so great joy that he lost al his cou^tenau^ce. And
fro hensforth he loved and desired so much Florence that he thought on nothing
but alonely on her. And thus departed Florence with the archbishop her uncle,
and travailed so long til at the last she arrived at Cornite on a friday about
the hour of euensong time, and there was received honorably, and there
remained a great season. And master Steven ever ^^rued her well and truly, and
she trusted more in him than any other after the death of the queen her mother.

How that the Emperor of Inde the more demanded of king Emendus the fair

THus the Emperor abode still with the king Emendus, and departed together
fro Pantopone and went to masedone, but ever the emperor was in great trouble
and thought for the love that he had in Florence ^oo that the king Emendus
demanded of him what he eyled to be so sad, and the Emperor answered and said

cannot set mi love in no place so well and nobly as on Florence your daughter,
therefore sir here with mine own mouth I desire you to have her in marriage. A

as she is desteined unto, for if that any other presume to take her he is but
utterly lost and dead. And also I have sworn and set to my seal to uphold

How that Arthur slew twelve knights, who had token away a young damoysell
fro her father and mother* and had tied her to a tree, there to have defouled
her vyrginitye, who was saved by Arthur. Capitulo.xxv.


ARthur Hector and Gouernar were riding after they departed fro the court of
the duke his fader.xv. days without abiding in any place, or fydinge of onye
adventures, whereof any mention is made. And rode so long that at the last they
came in to the country of 'noma^the and entered into a great thycke couerte the
which endured a great space, and at the last they found a great stange or water
and a fair grene medowe Ioynyng thereto the which contained the space of two
miles and a half, and so they rode still by the side of the medowe finally in
the botome of a great valey. Than thee espied a strong and our closed with
mighty wailes And arthur saw well how the gates of the place were open and so
they lyghted of there horses and entered into the toure and went up into the
hall, and all the way they found no creature, whereof they had great marvel,
and at the last Arthur hard the voice of a woman in a little chamber beside
him, who cried right pyteously and said. A lady vyrgyn mary help me and send
me some manner of so^our And therewith arthur lept into the chamber and there
found a right fair lady who had been drawn all about the chamber. And her
yelowe here drawn and cut of her head. And she was so sore b^ten yt she had
no power to help her self. And in this chamber there stood a table ready
covered, wherreon there stood wine and met great ple^te, whereof arthur had great
marvel and demanded of the lady who it was that had done so much trouble
and shame* And when the lady saw arthur and herd him speak, she was sore

hurt for I have harm enough all ready. Fair lady said Arthur be nothing
afraid for I will warraunt and defend you fro all enemies, therefore show

her feet and said, sir as god help me there departed fro hens right

How that Arthur Hector and gouernar slew.xxx thieves in a great forest the
which was a great wealth to all the country, for they had pylled and wasted the
country all about. Capitulo.xxvi.
ANd when Arthur was departed fro the varlet he and his company rode so long
till they entered i^o the same foreste that the varlet had showed them of
before. And rode all the day and could find no house nor mete nor drink for

acostomable there did repair.xxx. thieves who did rob all about where as
they could get any pray, so that no creature durst stere nor pass through
the country, and specially through y^ forest if it were any thing late. And
so by fortune these thieves encountered the stuff and caryages perteynynge to
Arthur and his company. And incontinent they took all the stuff and did bette
and intrete them that were conductours thereof, till at the last Iaket Arthurs
squyre drew his sword and to his power did help and ayed to defend his

and in the color thereof to have taken his wife to his dishonor, surely I

and drew his sword and stroke Gouernar on the helm so rudely that he was
therwyth sore a stonyed* where with arthur was sore dyspleased and blamed
greatli Hector therefore. And tha^ Gouernar said sir stryke me no more for by
the faith that I owe to our lord if ye do I will not pardon you, for ye shall
have as good as ye bring how be it as for that ye have done I will suffer it
for the honor here of my lord arthur and for the great lygnage that ye be of,
why good sir quod Hector what would ye do else any great hu^te that shall be
soon seen, and so stroke Gouernar again on the helm a great blow, ^her with
Gouernar drew his sword and rudelye stroke Hector on the helm for he was a
good knight, and so there began a great and a sore ba^ayle between these two
knights. And arthur did his pain with fayrenesse to depart them, but they
were so sore dyspleased and chafed each with other that Arthur coud in no wise
cause them to leave: And wha^ arthur saw that he drew his sword and stroke
Hector so rudely that he made him to stoop down to ye neck of his horse, and
with an other stroke he stroke Gouernar so sore that he was sore aston^ed
therewith and ^^e had fallen fro his horse, and than Arthur would have
recovered on him a another stroke, but Gouernar went from him. Than arthur came
to Hector and would have stryken at him again, but than Hector said cosyn what
will ye do, a^e ye dyspleased with me ye verily said Arthur right sore for
gouernar showed to you your folly, and ye therefore have stryken him here in my
presence, whereof I am not content. Sir said Hector I repent me but he
dyspleased me sore yt I could not refrain my self as at that time, well quod
Arthur now than fro hensforth be in peace, or by the faith that I owe to my
lord my father the first of you that begins shall lose my company And also
my good will for ever, therefore come on Gouernar and make ame^des unto my cosyn
Hector in y^ ye have stryken him sir said Gouernar with a right good will.
Than he put of his helm and desired Hectors good will, now cosyn Hector quod
Arthur make ye him amends, sir said Hector right gladly, for it forthinketh me
g^ea^ly the displeasu^e yt has been between us and so he did also of his helm.
And there each of the^ kyssed e^her and ^o entered forth into there Journey, and
rode forth so long till the were passed the forest. And than they suddenly
encountered the knight sir Delalaunde and the messenger that they had met with
the day before, and there each of them did salute other. Than sir Delalaunde
demanded of Arthur into what parties he would draw him unto. Certainly said
Arthur it has been showed me that at holy rode tide next coming there
should be at vienne a great assemble of noble men and good knights. Therefore
I am ridynge thytherwarde to se that nobleness. And to be acqueynted with some
of the good knights that will be there, truly said sir Delalaund it is of
troth that there shall be a great assemble of noble knights, for there shall
be a great tornay. I pray you sir said Arthur, for whom and for what cause was
it first taken, sir if I should show quod sir Delalaunde, ye should than know
some thing sounding to my velany, nevertheless it seems yt ye be a noble man
and the chyef of your company. Therefore I shall show you as I know.

How that sir Delalaunde showed to Arthur the occasion why yt this tornay was
first taken by the lord Beauiew. Cap. xxvii.
Sir it is of troth my lord yt earl of Beauiew has always loved me sith the
beginning of my youth and so it fortuned when I was young and lusty. I thought
to go play me out of mine own country acompanied alonely with my squyre,
hoping to vaynquysshe all the valor of the world. And so at the last I came
into the land of myrpois and fell therein acquaintance with two noble lords of
great lygnage, who did me great honor. And one of them had a right fair lady
to his wife named the fair lady of Rossylo^, for whom this tornay was first
taken. And she had such favor in me and love that within a little while I was
made chyefe ruler and senesshall of all her country, and was of her strayte
counsel. And nothing done without it had be done by me. For she trusted more
in me than in any other person of the world. And in like case I was with the
good lord her husband And so I continued in this love and favor well the
space of six years and more and it fortuned one year yt for my sake they kept
a christmas with open court: whereto came many knights of the country. And
when the first day of this began this lady of Rossilon wife to my said lord,
she was as than fresh lie appa^ayled as it apertayned to the feast and to her
estate. At which time to me she seemed so fair so gentil, and so proper that I
thought I had never seen her half so fair before. And as than her beauty
stroke so inwardely to my heart that I lost thereby both meat and drink yt
every day I began to wax so lent of body that every man had marvel what I
eyled. And demanded often times of me what was the cause that I so enpayred,
but ever I did as privily as I could but at the end it auayled me nothing.
For at the last love constrained me to show unto my love and lady all the
dolor and pain of mine inward heart. And on a day as it happened I tose very
erly For the thoughts of the night killed me. And right as than I found this
lady leaning in a window. And so boldly I lened me down by her and than she
gave me good morrow, and desired that g^d should send me health, well madame
quod I. Than the king that all has formed give you a better day tha^ I have
had a night. And also better health, for my h^lth is very far of, the which
^ight sore troubles me. Than this lady comed her to ward me and said, sir
how is it that your health is so far fro you might it not be brought nerer to
you for goldenor for silver. Madame quod I peradventure if I showed you ye would
put thereto no pain nor counsel, how be it ye might right well do it, so than
it were bette^ that I kept it still secret than to show it, and than to be
neu^r the nere. Sir said she I require you I will with all my heart be glad to
put my pain to bring you to ease and health wherefore it is a great shame for
you, for when ye may have counsel and remedy and will not seek for it, but
thus to suffer pain and vnhertes ease, the which I ensure you greueth ^ight
sore both my lord and me. Therefore good friend by the faith that ye owe unto
me show me your g^efe. And there with she came nerer to me and enbraced me in
her arms and showed me great sign of love an^ sweetness as these women be
acustomed to do when they will draw ou^ of a man's mouth that is enclosed in
the he^te. And when ^ saw her gentylnesse and sw^te behavior, my he^te was
rauesshed and brought into ye case that of a great season I could speak no
world for weeping. But sir quod this k^ight to Arthur though I show this unto
you my nysenes I pray you think no folly in it, but take it in gree, for in
deed sir yongth does many things. By my faith sir no more I will. And therefore
proceed forth in your tale. Sir than I said unto this lady. Madame what so ever
fortune fall thereof I will show you all my desire. Madame it is of troth I
have set my heart and al my thought on you more than on all the remenaunt of
the world with so faithful profounde love in mine heart as it well appereth' and
shall do by me, for another person I love nor can love, but alonlye you. And
therwi^h my heart failed me yt I could speak no word more, th^rwith I sat me
down and she by me. Than she answered and said, what sir Guy delalaunde it is
tha^ thus a ye say ye mada^ said I without fail, will sir quod she say ye
these words other to a^^ay me or else for very love. I require you tell me ye
troth by my soul madame quod I this that I have said is for the great myschit
that I am in without your help. Therefore lady for gods sake have pity on me
And th^rwith I joined together my hands with great vn^ase of heart. Than she
beheld me well and said, sir ye be a ^^ght wise and sage knight, therefore
behold well if you^ desire ^e not pre^udicial to any person, madame quod I for
troth I se and know well that I desire aga^st my lord treason and fa^senesse
who loves and hono^reth me so much above all other, how be it madame I se and
know well that yongth and love brings me to this, so that mesure and reason
fails in me* Therefore I had rather to dye than to live. ^han this lady w^o
was right wise and sage said, sir be in ^este and let joy increase in your
heart for w^ will speak more of this matter at a better leaser, ^his she said
to give me comfort, and not to the entente that she would in any manner wise
t^espace agaynst^ her husband, so this in thus manner I drove of the time a
great season, but as love as I could get her at a good leaser and convenient
place I was ever resoning with her of this matter, and lay importunatly daily
requyring her to have pity of my mortal distres, and so it fortuned on a day
that we were togeder leuynge in a window loking out toward a fair forest. Than
I spoke to her so fair and in so rufull manner that she could no longer drive
of my request. And said sir your suite is so importune that it behooves me to
assente to fulfill your desire and will, how be it sir se ye not yonder great
oak standinge in the forest yes madame said I right well, well quod she I am
content to fulfill your mind on this condition, look that this same day
twelve month and this same propre hour that ye fail not to be under yonder
oak and without fail thither to you will I come ready apparayled to aco^plish
your entente, and before that day look never for to have it. A mine own dear
lady humblye I thank you of your good will sith I cannot have it no sooner, at
the least I shall pass the time more (...) in h^ping of that fortunate day.
whe^fore I will take my leave now of you, for ye shall not se me again till ye
time be come, for if I should abide in your daily presence, your beau^eful
eyes should lea me to abide so long, for that thing that I desire. And so
than I took leave praying her to keep couenaunte with me. And so she ensured me
she would. Than I took license of my lord her husband, showing hi how I would
depart into mine own country for a season, and he was loathe to give me leave,
but wha^ he saw that I would needs depart he offered me to have forsaken his
own country, and to have gone with me, he loved me so entyerly. And so at the
last with much sorrow I gat leave and departed privily on a night and dysgysed
my self and went wandering about the country till the year was past. And tha^
this same day and hour that mine apoyntement was I came to the said oak in the
forest before the castle wyndowe, and incontinent I perceived where this lady
stood talking with my lord her husband in the same window where as she and I
made our apoyntement together. And than I made so many tokens and signs that
at the last she perceived me, and than she began to smyle, and when her lord
saw her laughe he demanded the cause why. And she answered and said, sir for
nothing, for nothing quod the lord I am sure ye will not laughe for naught
therefore show me the cause, for surely I will know it therefore I command you
to show it, sir quod she sith it pleases you I am content to show you, but
first sir I require you tell me wha^ that ye saw or hard of sir Guy
delalaunde. In good faith madame not of a great season whereof I am (...) sorry,
for y^ I had known that he would have ta^ied so^ long a space I would have
sough^ him out or this time, well sir quod this lady he is not now se^ hence,
sir it is of troth he has before this time desired me of love, and in a manner
his suite was impor^unate. And the love that he bare me was so fervent that he
was right sore dyseased thereby, the which was right well seen by him while he
was here with us, and so there this lady told the lord her husband all the

showed him and said sir this is the same day that I promised him to have

forgotten this matter, ^ut so sir ye may se him under yonder great oak where
as he is al a^naced because he finds me not there as I promised him. And sir
ye may se by him how yt these folysshe lovers are overcome with love And this
is ye cause that he departed f^o you, for he might not endure no longer the
great tourment yt he was in. Ye madame quod the lord is it thus, than I
comm^unde you on ye love that ye bear unto me that ye god and apparayle you in
the fresshest manner that ye can do and than come again hither to me. Than the
lady did his commandment and came again to him. And than he said. Madame I
will and also desire you as derely as ye think to keep my love that ye go to
yonder knight under the oak and suffer him to do what so ever he will with you,
and reco^maunde me heartily to him A sir said the lady for nothing will I do
thus, for if I had ever thought to have ful^ylled his folysshe desire, ye should
never have known it by my will. And sir if I would now do it, it were to me
great vylany, both tofore god and all the world. Madame said the Lord* I
will take all the sin on me, and I swear to you faithfully on my troth that I
will love you and keep you more derely ever after, therefore I will that ye do
thus in contynent* Well sir said the lady it behooves me thus to do sith it is
your pleasure, if honor come thereby take it to you, and if shame come
thereby ye must take it of worth. And so than this lady came in to the forest
(...), and us soon as I saw her I was never so joyful before. For I thought
I would quy^e all the World for her, than I came to her and enbraced her in mine
arm right swetely and said. My right dear lady my hearts desire ye be to
me right har^^^y welco^e. Sir delalau^de quod she, God put in to your heart
that ye do no wrong nor tresp^ce against any person. Sir my lord my hus^onde
hartly recommau^deth him unto you as to his own good feed H^w so madame quod
I, where is my lord Certainly said she he is here by in his castelle. But
madame said I how is it, does he know that ye be come hyder to me. Ye sir
said she as God help me, for he ha^he caused me to be apparayled in the
fresshest manner to the intent I should please you the better, and so he has
sent me hither to you to the intent to fu^fyll all your will and desire, and
therefore behold me here all ready for to accomplish your will, as for hurt
or ill shall none come to you, thereby neither by my lord, nor yet by none other
for him, and so my lord does faithfully assure you, and sends you word by
me that he loves you in a manner better than he does him self. And when I
hard the great courtesy of my lord, and how that he loved me as well as him
self, and how that he sent me the thing that he loved best in all the world to
fulfill my desire therewith, and how that he would suffer that vylany for my
sake, therwyth fell away clean all my folly and unreasonable desire. For than I
thought it was better to leave my sensual appetyte than to have done that I
had enterprysed in my heart, for I thought than it should have been to great
shame for me to do vilany to so noble a gentle lords heart Than I kneled
down before the lady requyryng her of pardon of the great outrage and folly
that I thought a^yenst her, desiring her for Gods sake to help to make my
peace again with the good lord her husbonde. Than she took me by the hand and
brought me into the castle before the presence of her lord. And as soon as
he saw me enbraced and kyssed me. Than I kneled down before him and cried him
mercy, and there the peace was made between us, and ever sith he has loved me
as Well as ever he did before or better. Now fair sir I have showed you al mine
adventure, the which is right Well known of many folks, and so it fortuned
yt but now of late my lord Beamen was at a feast with the earl of Forest, and
there my said lord took this lady Rossylon by the hand to dance, and the

this my lord and lady dance together, he said how that my lord of Beamen
should be the second. Than the lord of Beamen wist well enough What he mente
and said. Sir marshall as for sir Guy de la launde is a right good knight
both wise and true. The marshall answered and sa^d, his bounte apered well
wha^ he took his own lords wife. Sir said the earl of (...), though he
desired her love, yet I dare well say that he never trespaced ney^her against
his lord nor yet against her, for he did not dysguyse him self like a rybaude
for to come unto the wife of his foster as some has done yt I know right well
wherwyth the marshall was sor^ chafed, for it touched his own delyng and
said. Sir ye be but a ^ole to say these words to me. And thus they mul^iplyed
in language so fe^ that the earl of Forest and the earl of Neuers had much ado
to appease them, and so for this intent was the iournay taken o^ both parties
Which shall be this Wednesdaye next coming, and there will be many great lords
of the marshalles party, as the earl of Foys, the earl of mou^belyall, and the
dolphyn of vy^nes, and many other knights, and also Al^xander the young king
of m^logre. And of my lords party will be sir I^kes earl of Forest, and the

When ye se him ye will say it were pite but he ^hold have the vyctory. Sir

a good will I shall be with your lord. But sir I pray you shall this lady of

other great ladies and damoyselles, and also it is ordained by common accord
that he that does best shall be made l^ke a king over al other earls, barons,
and knights, that shall be there assembled, and shall be crowned with gold as
a king, and al they with all ye power that they can make shall be content to go
with him in battle Whether so ever he Will have them, and so fro thens forth he
shall be called king of the company, and this marshal entendeth to have this
honor if he may* for surely he is a good knight of his hands, and much
goodness is in him if his tongue Were not, but that little more shameth all the
remenau^t, as it does to all them that god has given an ill tongue unto.

How that Arthur had the honor in the tournay that was made at vyen between
the Marshal of myrpoys and the earl of Beamen, where as was diverse great
kings, earls, barons, and many other good knights right valyaunte, whereby
Arthur gate him great thank and praise and was greatly honored of all ladies
and damoyselles there assembled. Capitulo. xxviii


ANd after that sir Guy de lalau^de had showed all this process to Arthur and
to his company they rode forth togider and so came to lion surle rone and so
passed over the bridge and rode through the town, and in a fair medowe under
ye towns side they espied where tents and pauilyons were rychely pyghte at
whytch time there were assembled many great and noble kings, earls, barons,
and other knights, as well of the one party as of the other. And than sir Guy
de la launde send a messenger to the earl of Beamen certyf^eng him how he had
brought in valyau^t knights with him and that in any wise he should retain
them to be of his company. And when the earl of Beamen and the earl of forest
and the Earl of Neuers hard these tidings they came out of their tents, and
saw where sir Guy de la launde and Arthur and his company came riding. And so
when they came nere they lyghted and salewed these earls, who did behold
Arthur, and perceived well how that he was a meruaylous fair knight great
and bygge and well furnysshed, and seemed well to be of great fyersnes and of
great estate, and also they saw Hector a bygge knight and a well made both of
body arms and legs, and also they beheld gouernar who was a great and a
big man and well made thereto, and that these earls praised much these
knights in their hearts. Than the earl of Beamen took Arthur by the hand and
said Sir ye be right heartily welcome into the country of vyenues, prayenge you
heartily to take your lodging with me and with these other two earls here
present. Than Arthur said, sir with a right good will, and so they led him
into their tents, and there Arthur, Hector, and Gouernar were unarmed. And
when they were out of their harneys every man beheld Arthur for he was
meruaylous fair, so that tydinges came into ye ladies ^en^es how that sir Guy
de la lau^de was come and had brought with him three goodly knights, and
specially one of them who was the fairest and goodlyest that ever was seen, so
that there was no bruyte nor talking throughout all the host but of these three
knights. Some said of whence be they, who knows them, thus was the commoning
of them in every place. Tha^ Arthur and his company issued out of the tents
and beheld the fresshe baners and standards and stremers waueryng in the
wind, pyght before every tente and pauilyon, and hard also the trompettes
tabouryns, horns so wnynge in every corner of the field, and great coursers

of sheldes against the son and glysteryng of helmes and knights by great
company talking togider also they espied the great tente of the ladies, in the
heyght thereof pyght a great shinynge apple all of burned gold, and ladies and
damoyselles there in singing and dauncynge. Than Arthurs heart began to smyle
and said to Hector. Cosyn how say ye, is it not better to be here and to se
all this nobleness than to crepe in to our moders lappes. Yes verily said

was time to goo to their testes, and so than went to their lodging till the

ye will begin this tournay my lord the marshall is al ready. Now as god help me

Saint mary who is yonder knight he seems too be the best knight of the

knight here before. Than said the lady of Rossylon to the marshalles sister.
Madame behold how yonder strange knight flies, but your brother the marshal
holds again, I had wend he durst have gone no ferder for fear of your
brother. It which time Hector also for his part struck a knight with so great
force that he ouerthrewe him plain too the earth, and Gouernar struck an other
down^ horse and man, and put him self in the thyckest of the prese and did
maruayles in arms, so that all that beheld him praised him greatly. Than

strange knights right valyaunte, therefore madame for gods sake cause the
marshal your brother to absente him self out of their syghtes, and in your so
doing I think verily you shall do a great alms deed. Than Arthur rusht into
the gretest prease, and struck on the right hand and on the left so great
strokes and so heavy that it was maruayle, for there was none that ever abode
him but he avoided the arson of his sadel and fell to the earth. At the last
Arthur espied where there was a squy^^ holdyng in his hand a spoke or a great
piece of an old broken charyot, the which he pulled out of his hand with

the entente yt he should mayme or hurt no man, but with that piece of the
charyot he thrust in to the prese and gave therewith so great and heavy strokes
that all that he touched went flat to the earth. For he was of that
condycyon that the more he had to do, the more grew his strength* and
virtue, he vnbarred helmes and claue a soun^der sheldes, and maruaylously bet
down knights, for whom someuer he touched were so astonyed that either he

THe next day betymes Arthur arose and all the other earls, barons and
