How that the Marshall of myrpoys for enui that he had because that Arthur had
the honor of the tournay, and by he had beten him down, for he had we^de
himself to have been the best knight of the world, therefore he defied Arthur
and challenged him to Just. And how that Arthur vanquysshed him, and brake one
of his arms, and two rybbes in his side. Capitulo.xxx
THan the Marshall who had his heart enflambed with great ire because that Arthur
had put him to the worse, and also because he herd so much good and honor
spoken of him, whereof he had so great envy in his heart, and so great despyte,
that he could not hold him self in rest, for he bileued him self to be the
best knight of the world, than openly he spoke so high and loud that every
knight might here him, and Arthur also, saying in this manner of wise Certainly
this s^raunge knight can not swoune, when he is led by the hand with fair
ladies and damoyselles: and clothed with their mantelles, he lacks no thing
but a soft pilowe to play thereon with some of these damoyselles And when
Arthur herd him he answered and said. Sir if their ladies take me by the hand
I thank them thereof for it is by their courtesye and not by my deseruynge
therefore I love them the better and will be the gladder for to serve them and
to be a faithful knight to them al in general. For as god help me so much
is a knight worth as he can deserve praise of ladies and damoyselles. And the
Marshall full of ire answered. In faith as for you ye be but little worth and
that seems well when ye are fa^ne to take the reuersion of these ladies old
clothing. well sir said Arthur as for all that look what so ever they do to me
I am right well content therewith I think I have no thing of yours if I have
take it fro me if ye dare. Certainly said the Marshal if ye had any thing of
mine so would I do think not the contrary for I would not spare neither for
you nor for none other to take it grudge thereat who would. Than Arthur all
smyli^ge said. Well sir than I am right happy that I have no thing of youres
for if I had me thinks I should not keep it long by your will. And wha^ the

Will ye do so much for all these ladies sakes that ye and I may play together
with tWo fair speres. Sir said Arthur ye be so valiant a man that ye ought
not to be refused nor denied for so litell a request T^an the Marshal Was

promised it me, and therefore if it please him, I trust he will not fail me, if
he do I will say that he is recreaunte. Nay said Art^u^ by the faith that I
owe unto God I will not fail you. And so every man prayed god that the shame
might fall upon the Mar^hall, because of his proud disdainefull mind. Than
Arthur demanded incontinent for his ha^neis. Tha^ sir Guy de la launde went
unto the ladies tente, and showed the^m how that the Marshall had challenged
Arthur to Just with him again. (...) the ladies to him all his harneys, and
prayed god for to give unto Arthur the honor of those Justices. For they said
how that the marshal was a fool, and of an outrageous wil^ull mind, wherefore
they prayed unto god that he should speed the worse. Than dame blaunche said to
the lady of Rossylo^. Madame I bileue now that your straung^ knight shall have
yet or it be night great need of some soft bed to lie in your chamber, by
that time thy brother ^athe brewed a caudel for his heed, for I ensure you he
neue^ as yet encountered so dear a physycien. well madame said the lady of
Rossylon. Fair and easily, at the end shall be seen who shall win the
wager, as yet ye can make no boost for ye have won nothing. Tha^ Arthur and
the Marshall both did arm them and when they were both in the field there was
brought to them great speres and than they spurred their horses with so great
randowne that the blood dashed out of their sides, for they were both good and
redoubted knights, but ^he Marshal was not to be compared unto Arthur for since
Arthur was first made knight he fered no man living, wherefore the Marshall
did folly to enterprise any thing against him, but pride does oftentimes
many harms to his master, the Marshall at the first course struck Arthur and
brake his spear to his fyste, but Arthur for all that moved no more than though
there had been but a read broken upon him. But he struck the Marshall so
^udelye that he bare down horse and man to the earth Than began to laugh all the
ladies and damoyselles, knights, and squyers. Than the lady of Rossylon said
to dame blaunche. Madame your brother is not so fell and so outrageous as I had
wend that he had been, for he takes no more of the earth but his own length,
I think he slepeth, behold how pryuely he lies still. And han the Marshall
awoke out of his trance he was sore ashamed in that he was so overthrown and
demanded if he had overthrown Arthur, than it was showed him nay, wherewith
he was right sore displeased Yet than again he prayed Arthur on his knyghthode
that he would Just with him an other course. But all that ever herd him
thought he played the proud fool and counseyled him the countrary, but all
that auayled not, for he said he would needs yet Just ones again. And when
yt Arthur herd him of that mind, he had great dysdayne thereat and wexed
angry in his heart to considre his folysh presumptuous mind, and said well if
he will needs abide the second I think he will gladlye let the third pass.
So than they took much greater spears than they had before, and in great ire
ran together so egerly that it seemed the earth enfoundred under them, and
the Marshall stroke Arthur right rudely, for he was a good knight, and
sheuered his spear all to pieces, But Arthur hit him with his spear the which
was great and bygge, so that the sadell paytrell, girthes and all brast, and
horse and man went to the ground so rudely that with the fall that the Marshal
had one of his arms broken, and also two of his rybbes, and his body sore
bruised so that he lay still a great season with out mouynge, and than all the
knights that saw the stroke were gretely abashed and said each to other how
that the Marshall was beten down to the earth both horse and man, and in great
ieopardy of his life.

How that Arthur was crowned to be king of all the knights of the tournay.
And they promised him faith and troth to serve hi^ in deeds of arms always
and in every place where as it seemed him best, and the young king of ma^^gres
did crown hi^. Capit. xxxi.
THan wha^ the Marshal was thus overthrown the ladies did laughe, and said.
Blesse^ be god pride always overthrows his master. Than the lady of
Rosst^on said unto the lady blaunche. Madame now it seems that your brother
has l^ste the wager it had been better for him that he had been in your
chaumbre, he speaks no ^o word^s he has little care now for the flies behold
how that he ^aketh h^s legs Than all the other cou^cesses and ladies that were
there present^ did laughe, an^ said the pride of him is now well abated god keep
and defend such a knight that can give such valyaunte strokes As god help
me said the lady Rossi^on the Marshall is now in good rest. I trow he has
little lust to remount again let him be well apayed, for now he has that he
sought for. And so each of them spoke their verdyte. Than the young king and
the other Earls came to the Marshall and demanded of him how he did. And he
answered and said right ill, for I have two of my rybbes broken and one o^ my
arms. I pray you how does Arthur. In good troth said the earl of Beauieu,
he is yet in the fyelde, where as he entendeth if ye will goo to him and break
the third spear. Alas said the Marshall, I believed this day in the morning
that I had been the best knight of ye world, for I thought that there was none
that had any power in comparison unto me, but now I have found my mayst^r.
therefore I require you cause him to come to me. Than the earl of Beauieu took
Arthur by the hand and said. Sir the Marshall would feign speak with you. In
the name of god said Arthur let us goo to him. By that time the Marshall was
laid on a little couche that was brought to him. And when he saw Arthur he
said that all might here him Sir ye be to me right hertely welcome as he
that is the ch^fe flower of all chyualrye, and sir I cry you mercy of the
great pride that I was in, the ^hyche moved me to Just with such a knight as
ye be, verily I was envious and sorrowful of the noblenes that I heart spoken
of you, and therefore I took on me to Just with you, to the intent to abate
your praise and renown, but such there be that thinks to grieve other and
the hurt and gryefe tourneth unto them self, god has done to me right
according to my thought, for he has brought me in to the same case that I
had thought for to have you in, therefore gentle knight, I require you to
pardon my folly that I have thought agenst you. And when Arthur herd him speak
so louyngly, he had great pity of his hurt and said. A sir I ought to cry
you mercy because that I have hurt you so rore, wherefore it forthynketh me,
wherefore sir I pray you to pa^don me. Certainly sir said the Marshall, with
all my heart, and I give you my voice of the crownyng of this tournay as unto
him that is the best knight of all the world. Than the king said sir Marshall
than ye be accorded that h^ shall be crowned as the best knight of this
tournay. Sir said the Marshal as god help me with all my heart. and the king
said by the faith that I owe unto god, he shall have my voice and good will.
and all the other Earls said that they were all agreed thereto, for he was
worthy and none other. Than came to them all the Ladies and damoysels, and they
were all of the accord that he should be crowned as the best knight of all
other And than ye crown was brought forth and the young knyge of malogres
did set it on Arthurs head bye the common accord of all the hole assemble,
and they were al content that he should be king of all those knights that
were there assembled, and they all profred him succor and aid in all places
and agenst al people and as often as he would command them. Thus they
remained in great feast and Joy well the space of fyftene days, with all manner
of pastaunce sownynge to noblenes.

How that Arthur after his crownacyon took leave of the young king and of all
the other lords and knights ladies and damoyselles, who conuayed him on his
Iournay ward, and had great sorrow to leave his company. Capit. xxxii.
AT the end of the.xv. days arthur took leave of the king and of all the cries
and ladies who were not w^l content of his departing. And the king said, right
dear sir and friend I require you as hartelye as I can that ye will go with me
into my cou^^re, and I promise you faithfully as a king yt ye and I sha^be in
in all things as co^panyons and friends, and I shall love you right derely,
and will give you land so great and good that ye shall be right well content
therewith, mine own sweet friend I require you grant me my desire, and
therwyth he enbraced and kysse^ him. And when Arthur heard him he smyled and
said, mine own dear Lord I thank you, and would to god most puyssaunt that
I might do as ye desire me, for it were great Joy to me to abide in your noble
company, if it were nor for one thing that I have enterprysed and as yet I
wot not well what it is, nor where to find it, but as mine adventure
happenneth. I have tarried here very long, therefore now it is time that I
depart. And when they herd that he would needs go, they were right sorrowful,
and the king and all other offered him to go in his company to help and aid
him to attain his enqueste, but Arthur would not consent thereto, and said
that he would have no company but such as came within him. Yes sir said the
king ye shall have with you Bawdewyn my squire, and I will deliver him to you
for good and true, for I will undertake he would rather dye than his master
should take any hurt or damage in his defaute, and also he knows the virtues
of all herbs, for he is a sovereign surgyon. In the name of god said Arthur, I
am content to take him of you, and for his conning I will love him better tha^
two thousand pound of yearly land. Than Arthur, Hector Gouernar, Bawdewyn and
Iaket, took of every man ^oungy and leave, and departed and entered in to their
Iournay, and Bawdewyn and Iaket rode before. Hector and Gouernar rode togider,
and Arthur between them. And as they rode they comoned of the great valor of
the young king of malogres, and of the other earls and knights ladies and
damoyselles, and of the gre^e honor that they had among them. In this manner
they rode every day the space of three wekes without finding of any adventure
whereof any mencyon is made.

How Arthur and his company aryued in the erledome of Brewle, marchynge agenst
the land of Sorolois and entered into the cite of Brewle, the which was
besyeg^d by the duke of orgoule named Malaqu^s because ye earl would not let him
have his daughter in marriage, wherefore by false treson he slew the earl. Cap.
xxx^ii.
AT the end of the.iii. wekes Arthur and his company entered into the Erldome
of Brewle agenst the land of Soroloys, and of this erledome there was an Earl
a noble of hauoyre and of friends, and reputed right wise, and had to wife a
noble Lady and a virtuous, who had to name the gentle Isabell, and had
between them two a fair and a gracyous daughter named Alyce. Ioynynge to this
Erledome there marched a duchy wherein there was a Duke which was named
Malaquys, a cruel man and an enuyons. And this Duchy was called Orgoule, and
this duke had often and many times demanded of this earl, his daughter dame
Alyce to have in marriage, but the earl nor the good lady his wife would in no
manner of wise grant thereto, because of the evil condycyons that were within
this Duke. And when that the Duke saw that he could not get this fair lady
Alyce he bare than in his heart great heat and envy to the earl her father, in
so much that at the last, this duke had knowledge upon a day how that the
Earl was gone to chase in the forest. And thereby his prepenced malice caused
this Earl shamefully for to be slain and murdered. And when that the Earl was
thus myscheuously slain, he was brought home to his wife which was right
sorrowful for his death, and made him to be honorably buried. But this sorrowful
la^y in no wise could ve^yly tell how that he was slain, but she had great
suspecte to the duke. And so within half a year after the duke came unto this
counte^^e and demanded of her Dame Alyce her daughter, but the countes^e
because ^^e had him in suspecte of the ^^the of the er^e her husbonde would in
no manner of wise grant thereto, nor also this fair maiden Alyce would in no
wise have him to dye therefore. And when the duke perceived that he might not
have her at his pleasure he had g^^te ^esp^te thereof, and so defied the
coun^esse and assembled a great host and be ^yeg^^ the cite of Brewle, and
wasted all the country round about a great ci^cuy^e, and made his auowe that
he would not depart thens till that he had won her by force. And i^ this
mean season Arthur and his company arrived in that country, and the Duke had
layen at the syege as than the space of a year before the Cite accompanied
with four hundred knights besides other servants And thus ^rthur and his
company rode thro^ghe this Country the which he found all exyled and put to
wast, and met with much people ^leyng out of the land, whereof he was greatly
ameruayled, and demanded of two vytaylers that he met, ledynge of vytayle to
the host what was the cause of the exile and wasting of that count^e. And they
answered him how that the duke of orgoule had wasted it in such wise. Ye
fre^des said Arthur, and I pray you for what cause. Sir said they that will not
we tell you, for we have need to sell our vytayle to win thereby our sustenau^ce
and therefore it behooves us not to say ill nor to accuse any per^one, but if
ye will know ye may we^e of this people that ye se fleing out of the
country. Than Arthur demanded of them the cause, and they showed him how
that the duke of orgoule demanded in marriage the earls daughter, and how that
he caused the earl to be slain by treason because he would not agree to his
desire, and as now has besyeged the countess in her cite of brewle and has
wastee all the country. And when Arthur herd all this he said. Syrs god speed
and help you all* And when he was riden far from them he said to Hector his
cosyn. Cosyn how say you what is best that we shall do, Sir said Hector in
the name of god let us enter into this war. I allow it well said Arthur but we
will not aid this duke who is in the wrong and has the better hand. Nay
said Hector that is not mine intent let us aid them that be within the cite,
who be in great Ieopardye, and nigh put under wherefore they are in right great
fere, and this in my mind is best for us to do, for they ben in the right,
wherefore god will help and socour us. By the good lord said Arthur it is well
said, and so will we do. But how shall we enter in (...) the cite sith that this
duke ^ath besyeged it round about. well quod Gouerner we must enter by one
way or other. And thus they rode forth till at the last they espied the Cite
of Brewle the which was right hye and strong with high walls and mighty
toures, and round about the cite they saw tents and pauylyons pyght and
glysterige of standards, and streme^s wauerynge with the wind and much

time if it fortune you to encounter with him in the field. So they rode forth

her that she has not fulfilled your will, for now at the end she knows

it is of a troth al yt ye say, how be it I think there is none of her

For sir sith ye have said so much as ye have done I will desire and pray you

the earl of Bloys, who is a great Lord and a much redoubted. And when that
the countess and her daughter, and all her lords herd that they were right
glad and said how that God had vy^yted them Than Hector right heartily

they were fyaunced together. And than begau th^re a great feast and great joy
was made thrughout all the cite. Than the tables were set to goo to diner. And
when they were set they were right rychely served. And after dinner they
sported them togider till it was time to goo to their r^stes. In the next
morning Arthur rose betymes and herd mass, and than went up to the palace.
where he found all the barons ready apparayled, and there was Hector and

he would go with him But Arthur bad him never speak thereof if he would have his

How that Arthur went^ alone to the duke of Orgoule and gave him his answer
and bade him abide no longer for the fair Alyce. For he showed him how yt he
had given her to Hector his cosyn. And how that he had promised to her his head
because he slew her fader by treason, with the which answer the duke was
sore dyspleased, so much that there was bitwene them a great battle. Cap.
xxxiiii.


THan when Arthur was mounted on his horse, he issued out of the City all
alone. Than Hector said to Gouernar and sir Oaths. Fre^des let us take our
harneys, for I fere me leest Arthur thur shall have somewhat to do or he com
again. Ye have right well said quod Gouernar, and they armed them, and so
did all the men of war yt were in the cite. And wha^ they were all armed
they went to the batylmentes of the walls to behold the demenour of Arthur.
Who as than had rode so far that he descended sro his horse at the dukes
tent. And there he said to the duke. Sir verily I answer you how ye need not to
tarry here any longer for yt fair lady Alyce, for certaynely I ensure you I
have given her to my cosyn Hector, and all the lo^d that belongs to her both
by fader and mother, therefore sir in fair means I require you to depart
hastily out of this country, and if ye will not I have promised to ye fair
damoysel Alyce to render to her your heed in re^ompence because ye slew her
fader by false treason Than the duke was so sorrowful and replete with
displeasure yt of a great space he could speak no word. Than the duke had by
him a cosyn germayne, who said to Arthur. Sir knight ye do great outrage to
demand the head of my lord the duke, but by the faith that I ow unto him in
the first place that ever I mete you in I shall make him a present of your
heed. Ye sir said Arthur, and why will ye abide so long sith ye may do it now
if ye can, wherefore behold me I am here present, mount up shortly on your

seems my cosyn Arthur shall not come again without Iustes. Than the knight

heart, wherewith he fell down dead to the earth. And when the dukes knights
being in their tents saw him fall down dead they were sore displeased. And
also this knight had. v, knights to his brethren in the dukes host, and they
armed them all at ones to run at Arthur.

How Hector and Gouernar and sir Oaths rode out of the cite well accompanied to
rescowe Arthur, who al alone assailed the duke of Orgoule and all his army.
Capi. xxxv.
ANd when hector saw them of the dukes hooste ran to their harneys he said

How Arthur, Hector, Gouerner, and sir Oaths discomfyted Peter ye cornu, brother

When that Arthur had taken sir Clare^bault the Dukes senesshall and

How that Arthur and his company utterly dyscomfited the duke and struck of
his head, and did send it by Gouernar to the fair lady Alyce and to her
mother as he had promised before. Cap. l.xxxvii.

his present, and you for your labor, and for this message I give you dorge my

land of no creature without the consent of my lord Arthur. And when sir
Clarembaulte saw the head of the duke his master, he made right great
sorrow, and so entered into his chamber, and there he demened right great
doloure. Than gouernar returned again to arthur, and thanked him much from
the countess and from her daughter. And by that time Arthur had done so much
that all the Dukes company were clean by scomfyred as such people that had no
sovereign, wherefore they fled on all sides, and Hector and Gouernar did chase
them, and so brought many of them to their death.

How Arthur and his company went to the cite of orgoule for to take it by
force, but the Bourgeyses thereof brought unto him the keys, and did unto
him homage and so did all the nobles of that country as unto their chief
sovereign lord. Capit. xxxviii.


ANd when the battle was ended Arthur came unto sir Gace and said. Sir let as

and so remained there three days.

How Arthur made his cosyn Hector duke of Orgoule by the assente of all the
lords of that country. Cap. xxxix.
THan arthur called before him all the Lords and Barons of that realm and

How that Gouernar came to a strong castle called the brosse, and vanquyshed
the knight that kept it. And how that afterward he was kept in that castle

who shall cause to be openly proclaimed and to be said, behold the knight that

How Arthur after yt he had acheued ye adue^tures of the palace and delivered
the prisoners, and after how yt he acheued the adventure yt was in the galary
going in to the gardin of the mount perilous, and by his might with a great

thentent that none should pass in to the gardyns of the mount peryllous and so
than failed and ended all the enchauntementes of that place. Cap. xliiii.
AFter that Arthur had delivered these prisoners and acheued the foresaid
adventures, than the varlet came to him and said. Sir it is of troth that ye
have fordone and overcome all the adventures of this place saving one, and
that is in ye galery going in to ye gardyn and sir if that were for done than
every body might goo and come in to this castle as surely as in to any other

right good will said ye varlet, but sir we must have first some fire with us,
for ye galery is so derke that we can se no thing there, and so than they

other side, and they had each of them a great flayle in their hands, wherewith
they contynually beat down right, ye which was made by enchauntement, so that
no creature could pass by them without death, and when Arthur saw them he took
his sword in his hand and laid on with all his might on these macomettes, in
such wise that his strokes might well be herd of a great way but for all that
he could not enpayre them, tha^ he perceived well that his sword could do him
but little help wherefore he took in his hand agree bar of a door that he found
there, and there with he laid on so fast that finally he bet down both these

seclerely al about him, and with strayning of him self in this bataile his

country, and also he knows right well how that ye did at vyen in the

How master Steven went with Arthur in the palace wtin the castle to ye
intent to see the wonderful adventures that Arthur had there acheued. Cap. xlv.
When that Arthur had received the said drink and recovered there by his

How that Arthur fought with the monster, the most foulest and horrible figure
that ever was seen with man's eyes and so vaynquyshed him by his valiant
prowess and strak of his head and did send it to the fair Florence* Cap.

How that the king Emendus sent a knight named Brysebar acompanied with a
thousand men of war to thentent that he and his company should go fight with the
monster. And how the said knight arrived at the monsters pit the same season
while that arthur and the monster were fightyng togider, and there he and all
his company did se how that arthur slew the monster without help. Cap. l.
SO it was about the season that arthur should thus fight with the monster,
the mighty king Eme^dus held open court in his city of Sabar, and weth him
there was the emperor of inde ye more, for this city was right nere adjoining
to his empire, and also he was glad to be with king Emendus because of his
daughter Florence, who^ he would gladly have had to his wife and thereon he
trusted when the year were ones expyred. And at this feast were all the other
four kings, and the xii. peers of the realm of Sorolois and many other earls
and barons, knights and squyers queen's, ladies and damoyselles. Than there
came to the king many great complayntes for the hurt that the monster of
the brosse had done in all the country, than the king took counseyle for
this matter, and so he was advised and concluded thereon to send a.M. knights
armed to go fight with the monster. Than there was chosen a right valyaunte

When the mayre of the roche had caused the great ^omyn bell of the town to

How the neuew of Brysebar arrived at the court of ye mighty king Emendus with

SO it was that when Brysebars neuew was departed fro thens as the monster was

THus was Arthur received of the sauyer, who made him right good chere to his
power* and the same time the squyers enemies had there a spy, who returned and

How on the next morning the vylaine brought Arthur to another adventure nigh
to the toure tenebrous, where as he was first assailed with terrible monstrous
birds, and great griffons without nombre, and after yt he was assailed

shall here afterward. Capto. lviii.
IN ye next morning betimes Arthur rose and armed him and mounted on his horse
and took his wateuer following y^ vilayn, and so he rode forth till it was about
three of the clock, and than they entered into a great valey, and ever they rode
lowe^ and lower, it was than a fair season, for the son shone clear, and by
that time they had ryden two leges and a half, they were in much darkness that
they had clean lost the sight both of the son, and also of the day, for it
was there as dark as though it had be^ about midnyght. Than the vilayne said
to Arthur, sir knight can ye tell fro whens al this darkness comes, if ye can
for do it and make it clear, than shall ye get thereby a perpetual honor, and
know you for certain that as yet there was never none that ever entered any
ferder that ever returned again therefore if your heart fail you enter no
ferder for if ye do, ye shall dye as other have done here before Friend said
Arthur, how is it that all this darkness is here in this place. I will tell you
no more said the vylayne, but I read you be sage and wise, for it stands you
well in hand. And therewith Arthur departed fro them and entered into the

derkenes, and so they lost the sight of Arthur, but they might se the shynynge
of his sheld as far of as one might shote an arowe. Thus he rode forth well
the space of half a lege, and at the last he found a river great and deep, and
black as pitch, and the banks were so hye, that uneath the water might be

none could enter among them without he were slain and above his head flewe

sta^lings And Arthur did cover his head with his sheld, and the griffons

How Arthur bette down the great machomet sitting in the vessel of brass,
and therebye the wind was ceased. Capitulo.lix.
THan Arthur wence forth and thought to have gone boldly to this vessel of
brass, but ye wynd was so byg that he was fayn to lie on ye earth all alonge,
and so to crepe on hands and fe^e till he came to the vessel, and drew after

up on his fete and came again to the knight and demanded of him what tower it
was yt he saw stand before him in the derke, for all this season he had no
light but by the reason a^ the shyning of his sheld Tha^ the knight answered
and said, sir the duke of bygor has a neuew who is named sir Isembart, he is
lord of this place, and he has such envy to all people that he caused this
tour to be made by a subtle enchaunter, and all this great darkness which ye
have been in, the which endures.v. leges in circuit, in the which compass
there was no land ayred nor sowed the space of six years paste, and so all
such people as were wont to dwell therein are fled away and famisshed for
ho^g^e, and this enchaunte^ by his craft also made this river yt ye have
passed, the which never man did before this time without death, for ever this
darkness has contynua^ly endured saving one day in the year, and that is on new

of the ^est knights that could be found in all th^s land, how be it now
they have found their master, the which knights did provide for us ye said

were in all the number of.xii. persons, w^ kept always this passage between these

wtoute death. well said Arthur show unto me what is the cause, and from
whence comes all this darkness. Sir said he it comes out of a great pi^ce
that is in this toure, and there be great gryffons that descends down into
this pyt, and in the bottom thereof there is a great hideous fire, made so by
craft that no man can tell how, out of the which the^e ryseth so black and so
thick a fume and smoke the which ryseth out of this p^t by certain doors and
wyndowes, whereby the light of the son and of the brighte sky is so quenched
that it is ever contynually dark, the which derknes contains the circuit
of.v. leges compass as I have showed you before, wherefore all this country is
clean wasted and destroyed and all the people fled out thereof. And why said

it is of troth that here by there is an abbey of white monks who were wont to
be reputed right noble and of great possessions, and most commonly kings or
princes when they paste by that place they would there rest and herbour them,
and there they should be well served, and it was named the abbey of the grace
dieu, and the abbot is a right wise man and a noble, for he is brother unto the
lord of Argenton who was falslye slain by treason by this dukes neuew the
which fortuned to come to the said abbey upon an Ester day in the fore none in
the same season that the abbot and al his hole covent were in solemn
processyon, and because that the covent did not at his first coming leave the
service of god that they were in, to have laid the tables, and to have brought
him meat and drink to have filled his paunche, therefore he was so displesed
that incontinent he lepte on his horse, and so was departing and his false
enchau^ter with him, And when the abbot knew that, as soon as he might he
came to him and desired him to ^atye, but in no wise he could make him to
change his purpose: but in the most shamefullest wise that he could he rebuked
them, and called them foul rotten chur^es, promising to do them as great
dyspleasure as could lie in his power to do, so he has done as ye may se, for
he has caused them ever lyth to live in great darkness, and also he has taken
from them all their rentes and possessions which they held under him or in

not labor for their living for lack of light, wherefore many of them be

god has not be minys^red this five year. well said Arthur that is great
damage: but I pray the tell me how may this darkness be fordone. Sir said the
knight the enchaunter when he made this fire was right sore dysplesed because
that there sprang out of the earth even by this terryble fire a fair
fountain, whereby he right well knew that this fire should be quenched if any
knight might attain to come thereto, and to cast the water thereof into the
fire, and so than all the darkness should cease for evermore after.

How that Arthur entered into the toure tenebrous, and how he there quenched the
fire, whereby all the terryble enchauntemente ceased. Cap^o. lx.
THan Arthur said, friend bring me to this said toure than he went on before

the tou^re the which were of.xv^. speres length square out of the which there

thentent that no creature should approach nere to the walls, so there was none

the derkenes thereby was doubled throughout all the countre^, so that neither
candell nor torche could brenne in no place, nevertheless Arthur entered in at

him, for if there had not ben more valor in him than in any other he had been
there clean overcome, and always he went downewarde on the stayres and saw
nothing, but he felt so many great strokes that oftentimes thereby he was
constrained to knele on his knees, but he could not tell from whens they came,
or who did give them to him, and ever he flourysshed about with his swerd

he was feign to cover his head with his shield, for or else he had been
^^^sshed though he had been of yren, and always thus he went ever downwarde
on the stayres till at the last he came down to the botom, and there he

thereby that he was nigh overcome, and as he felt about him he perceived that
he was nigh the fire, and as he went ferder he found out the fountain by the
reason of the cold air yt he felt, whereof he was right glad, and so than
he took his shield and plunged it into the water, and bare as much water
therein as he could and did cast it into the fire, and ever he fetched more
water and contynually did cast it into the fire, and ever as the fire
quenched the darkness began to mynysshe, and the more water he did cast into
the fire, the clerer the light began to wax, and at the conclusion he did
cast so much water that the fire was clean quenched, than might he se
clearly all about him, than he perceived on both the sides of the stayres how
there stood great images of brass holding in their hands great maces of
stele the which had done him much trouble as he went downewarde, but than
their power was ended, for when the fire was quenched the enchauntement was
fynysshed, than Arthur wha^ he saw that all was done he returned up again

How after that Brisebar and master Steven were departed fro Arthur fro ye
port noyre they aryued at Cornite where as king Emendus was, and in his

How the emperor was aferde lee^t Florence should cast her love on A^thur,

How Florence when she knew that master Steven was come to the court she was
right glad, and how yt he with his policy gate her longer respyt, yt was till
bartylmewe tide next after. Ca. lxiii.
ALL this s^ason was ye noble lady Florence in her chamber making ^ight great

will toward her, sir now she is here comen to you as she that for thynke^h of
your dysplesure for she does not, nor will not do nothing that shall be
contrary to your pleasure and will, but she is, and eue^ shall be ready to
accomplysh your noble commandment according to her he^^e, the which is good
and true both agenst you and all other persons where as it ought so to be,
and sir sith it is so that my lord the noble emperor here present will do her
so much honor as to desire to have her in marriage, whereof humbly she thanketh
him, ^ut it is well the custom according to the state of every person to d^e
dyscretelye and wyselye in such a case, therefore sir it is conuenyent to dele
prudently in this ma^ter, for ye empe^our and you are two of the greatest, and
puissan^est persons both of hauour and of ^r^ndes that is now living, and my
lady Florence is the most ^ye and puissaunt pryncesse of all the world, and
as touching so hye and solemn a matter as of the marriage of ^hemperour of
ynde, and of the daughter of the hye and mighty king Emendas, this hye and
great solempniti^ ought not to be done privily in chaumbres in rest and peace,
but it ought to be done in the open presence of all the ba^ons of both lands
and realms, to thentent y^ if god send any issue between them that their
marriage may be known openly to al people of both realms, whe^by shall be
eschewed all grudge and murmura^yon, for ^han such issue shall be well known
for ryght^ul heir throughout bo^he the regyons, nor also it is not convenient
that this solemn feast that is this day of the holy ghost and this solemn
feast of this noble matrymonye should be made al but at one feast, this day is
so hye and prin^ypally a feast, ^ha^ every christen man ought to do nothing
else but ^aude and serve god, and sir at the day of this noble marriage let
there be he^e kings dukes, barons and other noble knights, ladies and
damois^ll^s, and let all these do such service as aperteineth for them to do
and than let these ladies and damoyselles dau^ce and sing, and give to these
new knights chaplettes and stremers, and set on their spear points, and let
these young lusty knights frusshe together their speres, and dasshe together
with their swerdes, and let than be ordained round tables to assemble together
such company as shall be brought thither both by you my lord the king, and also
by the emperor than shall we se what knight is of valor and praise, at the
which time shall be brought hither the rich pauylion of my lady Florence
wherein is the image of the fayry holding the rich chaplet, so yt when the
tournay ^hal be done than my lord the emperor shall go to the image to have the
chaplet as he yt is right rich bo^^ of hauour and of friends, and the most
nobl^ parsone yt there shall be assembled, and to him the image will give the
chaplet as to him that is most wor^hy, and when he has it than he shall be sure
and certain that he shall have my lady Florence with good will and entyre
love, and that maryag^ yt is made with go^d love and heart is good, and that
that is contrary against the her: is right ill and I^op^rdous For a body without
heart is as me^e without salt, or as a body without soul, and thus may my lord
the emperor have my lady Florence with great love Joy and feast. And when the
emperor had well herd the master and saw how yt he spoke no more his heart
laughed in his body and said. By the faith that I owe unto god the master
has right well said, and ve^yly with a great good hert^ I me acco^de to his
devise, let this Io^full day be set and let there be c^yed a great Iustes and
a tournay against y^ time, and let there be ordained round tables to m^ke feast
and Io^e, and sir king the same day I will take the tournay against you all in
love and favor. As god help me said the king I am right well agreed, and mine
advise is to let all this be here in this cite of Cornyce. But what day shall
all this be on. Sir said the master and it please you I shall show you mine
advise, let it be at Bartylm^we tide next coming, for than ^hal all corns be
avoided out of y^ feldes, and by that time al thing necessary may be
honorably provided for. I am content said the king, but how say you my lord
the emperor. Sir sai^ he I am right well content. Than anon these poyntementes
ran over all the palace in every man's mouth, and every man prayed y^ god
might send to the master right good adventure for his well and goodly
speaking. Than began again ^ight great feast and Joy, tha^ came forth Iuglers
with ^heyr falls castes and tomblers with they soubersawtes, and damoyselles with
their gambawdes, and made greater sport and tryumphe than was before. Than the

these new knights go with me to my lodgyng and though I ^etayne them with me

and make them as good chere as ye can^ than Florence departed and went to her

love there to show part of his ^hyualry. Well master said she ye say right

^han he should bring with him Florence pauilion with the egle of gold and the

Thus al ^hese kings ^^ke their l^ue ^ depa^ted every man to his own country to

neuew of the duke of bigor. A fair master said Florence I have great doubt of
Arthur, for the dukes neuewe is right fierce and fell, and a good knigh^,
th^rfore I am in great fear of him. Madam quod he have ye no dout, for if

and departed and took with him Brysebar and sir Neuelo^ Florence mar^shal and so
took their way to arge^ce. Now let us leave to speak of them, and let us
return again to Arthur.

How that Arthur was received o^ the i^yre Lady Margarete into the city of
Argence. Cap. lxi^ii.


THus as ye have herd before Arthur so iourn^d a good space at the abbey of
the grace of ^i^n and Mawdelayne tide began fast to approach, and so on and
day the foul vylayne came unto him and said. We be but swyne for we do
nothing but eat and drink, I ^rowe ye be wedded to this abbey, or else I
think ye will become a monk, ye have promised me to fulfill my request, if
that ye will do so go ^hortely and arm you, and let us go^ ^o Argence to help
there the fayrelady Margarete of Argenton* and to get her again her right,
for it is now almoost hye time. When Arthur heard him he smyled and said, with
a right good will, and so he armed him and took leave of the abbot and of ^he
covent, and mounted on his horse and followed the vylayne, and so Arthur rode
forth day by day till at the last he descended down from a great mountain
and entered into the fairest medowe that ever he saw in all his life, and by
the side of this said medowe there ran a fair river, wherein were many
ships, some under sail, and some redye crossed, and some lienge at the
anger, the which river ran thrughout part of the fair Cite of Argence. And
than he encountered a varlet who came straight fro the Cite, and A^thur did
salute him and demanded from whence he came, And he answe^ed and said how
that he came from the Cite of A^gence, the wofullest Cite of the world at this
time, and is in most tourmente and sorrow, for I am sure there was never ^owne
so sore troubled as it is at this hour. And wherefore goo^ friend said Arthur.
Sir as god help me there is good cause why for the duke of bygor and his
n^uewe be com^nge to the Cite, and they have made a cry throughout all the cite
and all about the country that all the noble men and al other such as holds
their londs of the heir of Argent on should be at Mawdelayue tide next
coming before them in ^he cite of Argence to do their homage to sir Isembarte
the dukes neuewe, wherefore I pray to god he may dye an evil death, and it is
but.xv. days to the said day, at which time he is purposed to wedde the
fair lady margarete to a lewd harbor of his, and so she shall be dysheryted
fro her enherytaunce, and all the noble men and bourgeyses of the Cite and of
the country about are right sore dysmayed for they wot not what counseyle to
take in the ^ase for lack of a Capytayne, and ^he lady has no friend but an
uncle of hers, who is put in prison by the dukes neuewe, and there is none can
tell where he is become. And also this sir Isembart has slain and murthred
falsely by treason her father, and sir this is the sorrow that is in the noble
cite of Argence* well good friend said Arthur god conduyte you, god is yet
puyssaunt enough to send h^lpe to this lady, but fr^nde I pray you is this
duke and his neuewe come as yet to the Cite. Sir as god help me he is come al
ready, and with him much people, for his people is no^bred to a.M. persons at
the leest. That is a great company said Arthur, and so they departed, and
Arthur rode forth. Than the vylayne began to cry he is come that shall give
light And ever as he rode he beheld on every side about him great co^panyes of
knights coming and going toward the cite of Argence, and Arthur saw well how
that the land of Arge^ton was the most good lie country that ever he saw,
for he perceived well how that it was full of riches and worldly wealth, he saw
many noble towns and ^oures right hye, and mighty castelles, and many fair
woods and medowes^ and pleasant ryuers, and about ^he towns fair vynes, and
goodly pastures, and fields with corn and fruit and there he saw many ladies
and damoyselles sporting them by the ryuers side with fawcons and gerfawcons on
their hands and so he perceived well that because of ye good comod^ties of the
country ye dukes neuew would disheryte the fair lady Margaret, and he rode so
long til at the last he saw the fair city of Argence shining agenst the
son, enuoyred with great and deep dythes full of water: ye walls strongly
enbatayled, and mo than.v.C. toures made of lyme and stone, and sciment about
it and also he saw many fair churches coue^ed with led full of typpes and
pomelles of gold shynyng against the son, and also he saw the burgeses
lodging closed with hye and strong walls barred with great chains of iron
attaining fro one house^ ^an other, than Arthur in his he^ praised much the
nobleness and riches of the country and of the city, and said to him self
that it might well be called Argence, for it seemed well to be of argent that is
to say, silver. Thus Arthur entered into the city and the vylain went ever
before him with his lever on his neck bare legged, and his hat hanging at his
back and ever he went forth a great pace loking downward to the earth, and
took head of no body that he met, but always cried out aloude he is come that
shall give light, and the burgeses beheld him well and said how that he was a
fool, women and children ran to the wyndowes to behold him. And when one body
spoke to him, he would answer no thing but always said, he is come that
shall give light. Thus Arthur rode forth into the city and saw there
nothing to do, nor no manner of craft or occupacion there used no more than
and ^t had been upon an hye f^astfull day, for all the shoppes and every craft
was she^ and closed, whereof Arthur had great marvel, and he beheld in every
street great companyes of knights walkyng a^ soberly together, lurkyng under
their hattes, beseming as though they had not be well pleased, and some sytting
before their own doors, croslegged leaning on their elbowes, making no manner

who never ceased crying, he is come that shall give light. And so in this manner
Arthur rode ever still forth till he came into y^ mids o^ the City, and
there he saw a great company of knights and burgeyses about the number

had no great joy in the^^ hearts. Than the vylayn enforced him self to cry

se well yt I must needs go ferder ^o seek mi lodging Sir said the knight*

How that the next d^y the master answered for the lady, and Arthur took her

IN the morning the king and Arthur rose and all other barons and knights of

in the same plyte as he was in. And wha^ the common people of the country saw
the duke desire the lady to pardon his neuewe, they were in great fear
least that she would have granted his request, wherefore a great company of
them rushe into the prese till they came there as sir Isembarte lay still, and
they all at ones laid on him in such wise that they left no joint together
with other. And wha^ the duke of Bygor saw that he was afraid of him self,
and so took his horse and fled his way homewarde into his own country as fast
as he might. Tha^ the king of Orqueney said. Madame god and this knight has
this day done you great honor. And than sir Philyp demanded of Arthur how
that he did Sir said be right well I thank god. Than al these lords and
knights mounted on their horses, but the lady and much^ other people went
barefoote unto the great cathedral church of the city, and ^here she

Arthur and sir Philyp and all other lords and knights came thy there on
pylgrimage and than the bishop and all the hole clergy received Arthur with
solemn processyon, and so for great joy all the belles of the city were
ronge three days together, and all the burgeses throughout every street where

cloth of gold and of sylke, and rych carpettes and cusshyns and coueringes of

the great vylayne ran ever dauncyng before for Joy, and cried ever now darkness
is turned to light. And when the king had brought the lady to the palace he

said she god grant you y^ hye Joy, of heaven, and keep and preserve my good
knight yt has delivered me fro mine enemies and saved my land. Tha^ anon

to me my land the which was lost as to my use, for I had nothing thereof, and

and of you, wherefore I will to you make faithful homage, and take you for my
lord the which knowledge I will make here openly before all the nobles yt be
here present. A madame said Arthur for gods sake say ye never so to me, for
that shall ye not do. Sir said she ye have given it to me, and of you I hold

lord and father is de^d the which I thank mine enemies, but now they have

and come to you where so ever I shall be. Sir said the lady god give you a.C.M.
thankynges, but sir I swear to you by the faith that I have borne to my lord
and father yt I will keep no fo^e of land of y^ ye have given me without I make
to you homage therefore. And wha^ the king herd that he said to Arthur, sir take
her homage sith ^he will needs do it, and in like wise counseyled him duke

and Joy as could be devised, the which Joy endured but a little season, for
all their Joy was soon turned into great trouble, for all the court was in
great displeasure as ye shall here after, who lysteth to read or here thereof.

How the same season while the king of orqueney and all these other noble
people were at dinner in great Joy and mirthe there came in a messe^ger fro the
wounded knight to Arthur des^ringe him to come and help him or else he wol^e
wy^e him of his death, wherwt all the court was sore troubled, and ceased all
their Joy for the love of Arthur, for incontinent he departed fro y^ court and
went forth with the messenger, and how yt all the court fered greatly Arthur for
that enterprise, for there was never non that ever returned again alive fro
that adventure. Caplo. lxvi.


AS this noble court was in this forsaid great Joy and while y^ they were at
dinner there entered in to the palace on horse back a squire his sword gyrte
about him with his heart in his hand, and when he approached nere to the table
where as the king sat he began to cry as loud as he could, where is the
knight that is called Arthur of brytayne, if he be in this court let him
answer me, and with those words all the court was in peace, so that every
man might well here him. And when Arthur herd how that he demanded so for him
he answered and said. Friend if ye demand for Arthur of Brytayne there be
many folks reputeth me to be the same therefore behold I am here redye, for I
am the same man that ye demand for say what ye will. Sir said the squire I
am sent to you, therefore ye shall here what I shall say, sir it is of troth
how that my master sir Octhebon of hurtebise has heard tidings of you and
of your adventures, and so has he done of many other that could do him no
good, sir this knight is very seek in his body, for I think verily he is nere
to his death, therefore he sends to you by me that in co^tinent with out any
longer delay that ye come to him and give him health, accompanied al only but
with your squire, and if ye do not thus incontinent through your defaute he

and all this noble court. And than Arthur answered him and said, friend how
is it so that I should give him health, I am but an ill physycyon to help him
that is so seek as ye speak of. Sir come on your way and he shall show you all
the manner of his sekenes. well said Arthur thinks he than that I can give him
any good counsel. Ye sir said the squire if ye be of that hardines and valor

and I shall this day take my leave of all these barons and so follow you. Sir

appeleth you of his death. In the name of god said the king of orqueney of an
ill death I pray to god that he may dye, for he has caused the death of many a
noble knight, and so he will do now of this knight, and so shall we left his
company. Truly quod Brysebar would to god I had here his head. Tha^ the squire
answered the king and said, sir if I might answer a king I would say that ye
should not curse my master before me, and as to you sir knight that would have

gold, ye would fain have it so it might cost you nothing but ye were never so
hardy to go seek for it, the cause is ye du^st not, and as to you sir knight
Arthur ye cause ^e to tarry here over long, either come on your way or else
abide ^ere still, and so the squire was going his way. Than Arthur stepte fro

How ye Gouernar in serchyng of Arthur had the honor of a tourney yt was made
by ye earl of the isle perdue, and there Gouernar was amorous of the cou^tes And
how ye the ^rle charged the cou^tes yt she should not speak to Gouernar, whereof
evil came to him, for the next day Gouernar did bette him well in the
tournay, and lay all night after with the countess his wife. Cap. lxvii.


IN the morning betymes Gouernar took his leave of the lady and of the master,
and of the noble Marks and rode forth on his way and Iacket his squire with
him, and he was right rychely beseen, and mounted on a good and puyssaunte
horse, and so rode forth.viii. days and never could here any tidings of
that he sought for, till at the last he tryued in the lands of ynde the more
between the realm of soroloys and the empire, and there he saw a great river,
and at a cross way he encountered a messenger, who bare a scochyn on his
breast, and also a bode full of letters, and rode a great pace, and this was
aboun^e saint Laurence tide. Than Gouernar did salute the va^l^t and demanded
of him what tidings and of whence he was. And he answered and said, sir I am
pertaining to the earl of ^he isle perdue, and am riding to the strong
castle to a knight named sir Iakes to thentent yt he should come to him to go
with him to a tournay, for the emperor of ynde has somoned my master yt said
earl to wait on him to Corynte at this Bartylmewe tide n^xte coming, because
of a turnay that is taken there between him and the mighty Eme^dus king of
Soroloys, and because my lord thinks not to be vnpuruayed of good knights,
he has made to be cried a tournay on mondaye next coming to thentent to those
of ye b^st knights yt comes thider to have them with him to the said great
^ournay a^ Cornyte, therefore I must go to the said sir Iakes to cause him to be
with my said lor^e on monday next coming. well good friend said Gouernar go

hap right well that we may there here some tidinges of mo lord Arthur, and so

^hey ^ounde many knights yt were ready come^ so yt all the ^o^gyng^s were taken

a ^^gh^ valiant man and a hardy kn^ght, for there are but few that may

Than the porter went to the earl and said, sir there is at your gate a

How that Gouernar did beat down at the tourney the earl of the isle perdue.

How that after Arthur was departed fro Argenton to go to the castle of
hurtbyse to the wounded knight who had sent for him, in his way at the last he
found at the entryng of a fair forest three ladies of right excellent beauty,
of whom the chief was called Proserpin queen of the fayry who greatly desired
Arthur of his love, but in no wise he would agree there to, and there he lost his
varlet that was his guide, wherefore it behooved him to tarry there all that
night, for it was dark and wist not whyther to go. Cap. lxix.
SO it was that when the king of orqueneye was (...) f^o argenton he rode

for as much as he may he will let you to have her, how be it she shall be yours

have her after your war be done, and in your war I shall help you
with.xi.M. haw bertes, it is I that sent for you in the name of the hurt

hurt knight and demanded of him how he did, and whether yt he had well quytte
his couenauntes or not. Sir as god help me quod the knight I do right well, and
ye have right truly and nobly quytte you to me, therefore the lord yt all
thing fourmed reward you, and truley I am and shall be your own knight. And
so Arthur commanded him to god, and the lady also that was his love, and so
rode forth his way toward Cornyte.

How that Arthur when he was departed fro the queen proserpane it fortuned him
to take his lodging with the neuew of sir Isembarte, who took Arthur and locked
him fast in a toure to thentent to have slain him by night, but there Arthur
did so valyauntly that he brake out of the toure and slew the knight and all
his people. Capitulo.lxxi.
SO it was that when Arthur was departed fro Proserpyne he rode so long till
at the last he entered in to the land of the duke of bygors neuewe and so by
adventure he took his lodging with a knight who was neuewe to sir Isembarte,
and he received Arthur with great Joy, than he was unarmed, and when he was
redye went into the hall where as this knight was. Tha^ the knight demanded
of Arthur what was his name. And he yt doubts nothing answered and said, sir
I am called Arthur, and my squire is named Bawdewyn. Than the knight knew well
yt it was he yt had ^layne his uncle sir Isembarte, wherefore his heart rose sore
against him, but he made no semblau^t thereof, for he knew well that Arthur was
a knight right sore to be redoubted, for he wy^te well he was not able to
resyst against him, therefore he thought to slay him in his bed a sleep, and in
the mean time ^o close him fast^ in a toure, and than to send for the duke of
Bygor and al his company, and there to fle him by night time. And than he made

ye have slain sir Isembart, for of all men living I hated him most, for he

your head, for ye may say ye be unhappy to come hither to your mortal enemy.
And wha^ Arthur herd yt he was in his heart right sore dyspleased, and so ran
to the door thinkinge to have opened it but he could not: for it was barred

rudely darts and quarelles shot out of the crosbowes. Tha^ Arthur took his

they could in no wise hurt him. Than Arthur lepte out at the wyndowe and so
descended down and covered him with his shield. Than they all ran at ones at
him, but Arthur gave such strokes that he dashed down all that ever he attained

of his power. And at the last Arthur ^ncountred the knight of the place, and
gave him such a stroke that he claue him to the sholdres and so fell down
dead to the earth. And than anon after he disco^fited all the remenau^t, for
he delte such dyscyplyne among them that he cut of arms, hands, legs, and
hedes, and all that ever he attain unto Than Bawdewyn ran and did lift up the
draw bridge, and did shytte fast the gates to thentent that non should escape
and so they serched all about but they could neither find man nor woman,
and than they went to their restes til the next day, and so went forth on their
Journey toward Cornyte.

How that Gouernar in searching of A^thur by adventure he passed forby the
same castle where as Arthur had slain the lord thereof, and there he was

he slew the most part of them, Capitulo, lxxii.
ANd when that Arthur hadd well ryden four leges, than was it known how that

and as they made this sorrow it fortuned that Gouernar passed forby the same

How that Arthur found.xl. knights who had taken a damoysell the which they

ARthur rode forth so long till at the last he came to a great forest, and as he

How that master Steven departed fro the port noyre to go to the tournay at

How sir Rowlande of Bygor apeched Arthur of treason because that he had slain
his cosyn at Argence, and so defied him at the vt^eraunce but Arthur at the
first stroke drove him down horse and all to the eart^, and brake one of his

saw her loved Arthur whom she never saw before. And how after sir Rowlandes
servants assailed Arthur to have slain him, but he valyauntlye defended him
self and slew many of them. Capitulo.lxxv.


ANd after dinner the archbysshop and master Steven and sir Rowland and the
other barons went talkyng and playing togeder out of the medowe and entered into
the forest, and at the last they came to a fair grene oak the which did cast
a fair shadow a great cyrcuyte about it, and the grass was fair and soft

Yea yt ye have said sir Rowland and that tyght greuousely for ye were at

chief cou^seller with the knight that slew him, therefore I bear grudge in mine

a man can not attain to do so much as he would do, nor paraduenture he can

right was done, for godlightly will suffer no wrong, but always he fordereth

How Florence and Arthur spoke together at good leyser at the end of the

Madame said Arthur I r^quyre your grace to pardon me, for she may be such a

the heart puts outward the word of the mouth, as the wind puts away the

^o than every man returned in^o th^yr own tents and ^odgynges. And the

How that Arthur had the honors o^ the tou^ney the first day, the which was
made for the fair Florence between the king Emendus and the E^perour who
would have had Florence to his wife, on the which day Arthur gate him self
great praise among all the barony, in so much that every knight was glad to
be in his company, whereof the fair Florence was ^ight joyous, for she loved
him above all other. Cap. lxxix.
IN the next morning all the kings and other ^ose and herd mas^e, ^ such as
would took a sop in wine, and than eueri man Armed him. Tha^ Gouernar and
Bawdewyn by the commandment of Arthur did give and depart man^ horses and
much harneys to sundry knights where as they saw mister and need, the which
knights thanked Arthur right hertely and promised to give him their help and
socoure at all times, and against every man, whereby it appears that there is
nothing but by large gifts it is made soft and meke. Than the tidings of
Arthurs courtesye was spredde abroad in every tente, and there it was said how

renown, and counseiled her to love him well. And thus was king Emendus mounted

And when Arthur who as than had dyscom^yt^d a great company o^ knigh^es s^w

praised gretely that deed He is the best knight of the world said the king

makes many chyppes, I trow all the fendes of hell has sent him hyder, shame
