true sir said the bishop. Than Arthur saw where there was a great company of
knights well to ye nombre of.ii. hundred in a route, and among them was the
earl of the isle perdue, and he had taken more than.xl. of Florence knights,
and unhorsed them and was ledinge of them forth as prisoners. And when Arthur
saw that he was right sorrowful, and so by great randon he dashed in among
them, and there did such deeds of arms that all that beheld him wondered at
his valyauntnes, for it seemed that he was but newly come to the tournay, he
claue asonder sheldes and vnba^red helmes and braste asonder gyrthes and bette
down knights together on hepes, and Gouernar with his lever delte strokes right
rudely, wherewith he brought knights a sleep, so that some of them wyste not
which way to turn them. Tha^ came to him the king of orqueney, Brysebar,
^he senesshall, sir Miles, and sir Ansell and many other knights, and so by
that time there was horsed again a.xxv. of the knights that were before taken
prisoners, and there they delte so with their enemies that the earl of the isle
perdue was sore dyspleased, and he and a.xviii. in his company ran all at
ones at Arthur, and there by forse they slew his horse under him, wherewith he
was right sore dyspleased, and than stepte up on his fete and gave so many
great strokes and heavy that he cast every man to the earth who so ever he met
withal, and than he repented him that he had not born with him that day
cla^ence his good sword, how be it he gave such strokes yt none du^st aproche
to him, but every man fled fro him. And when Goue^nar saw Arthur a foot in
that great prese, he aduysed well the earl of the isle perdues neuew who was
right well mounted on a good horse, and so took him with his one hand by the
neck and pulled him down on his horse mane and gave him a right great stroke
with his le^er between his sholders, and as he thus held him Arthur came and
took him by ^he leg and ^u^bled him over his horse out of the sadel and threw
him to ye earth and so took his horse and did mount there on. And when the earl
saw his neuew on the earth, he spurred his horse to come to his rescowe. And
than Arthur enbraced him so at his coming and spurred so his horse that he
drew him clean beside his sadell, and in the spite of al his enemies he took
him prisoner and caused him to be yielded to king Emendus, and so was put into
the keeping of the fair Florence, and tha^ she caused him to be unarmed, for he
was right weary and was very hot and sore chafed. And than Arthur dashed intoo
the prese, and there did what he list him self, for he bet down knights and
wan horses and the emperor saw well how that he al only discomfyted his
knights, the which grieved him right sore, and also the duke of bygor was right
sore dysplesed in his mind because he saw Arthur do all that day so nobly,
and at the last he knew well how that was he that had slain his neuewe at
the City of Argence, wherefore he would feign have runned on him to have slain
him, but he doubted much ^he king of orqueney. Than he said to the emperor,
sir the earl of the isle perdu^ is taken prisoner and all your knights clean
dyscomfyted, the which is ^o you great shame without so be that ye pu^ thereto
some other manner of r^^^dy, and all the shame that is done to us, is done by
yonder knight with the white sheld^ and by the other knight with the great
l^uer, and verily it is he that slew my neuewe sir Isembart at Argence, and
sore wounded my cosyn sir Rowland* and also he has slain sir Fyrmont my
tresourer and so he has done me right great damage, and I know well he is a
right fair knight and a young, and of his hands such as ye may se* and this
I say because of your love Florence whom ye shall have, but his prowes and
goodness parauenture may cause her to love him for the heart of a woman is sone
turned and changed, this knight has done you al ready ^ight great damage, and
is likely to do you more without ye take right good head, and put thereto right
good counsayl Therefore sir I require you let me have the tourney to morrow, and
I shall so handel him that I promise you he shall not be here again on the
third day. well sir said the emperor I grant you your desire. Sir said the
duke I thank you, and so they left their talking as at y^ time. And Arthur all that season laid on round about him as freshely as though he had but newly
begone the tourney, and the king of orqueney beheld him meruaylously and spoke
never a word, and when he had long beholden him, he took at his hye prowess
such hardynes that he habandoned him self intoo the prese, and laid on freely
with his sword. Than the tourney was more greter and more thycker than is was
of all the day before and so there Gouernar brake his lever, tha^ he laid hand
on his sword and did therwyth as much as any good knight ought or might do.
And so at last Arthur and the king of Orqueney did so much that they unhorsed
all the earls company and were set on foot sore beaten, in so much that they had
much pain to stand on their fete. Than Arthur stood in the field with his sword
in his hand saying, lords if there be any moo that will come let them prese
forth, I am ready to answer them, and so at last ye king of orqueney and he
returned fro the field. Than the king Emendus encountered them and enbraced
them all armed as they were, and specially Arthur and thanked hi^ much of the
pain that he had suffered y^ day, for sir all only by your prowess this day
themperours people are dysco^fyted. And as they were thus talking together there
came to them a knight f^o ye duke of bygor who said to ye king Eme^dus, sir the
duke of bygor demau^deth of you the tourney to morrow. Than stepte forth the
king of mormall and ^ayde, sir may i^ plese you to suffer me to have to morrow
the furney agenst the duke of bygor. Sir it pleases me right well said the
king Emendus, therefore I desire you do your part, for we have the honor this
day, therefore do your pain that we may have it also to morrow. Sir said he
doubt not I shall do my true deuoyre, tha^ he took Arthur by the hand and said
Gentle knight flower of all chyualry I desire you as hertely as I can do so
much to morrow as ye may win a king for evermore as yt it would please you to
show part of your hye prowess to morrow in ayding of my quarrel, and in the
defense of the noble honor of my lord ye king here present. Ye sir said the
king Emendus and thereto I will desire you, for by your hye prowess we have the
honor this day, therefore it should grieve us gretely and we should lose it to
morrow. Tha^ Arthur said, sir with a right good will I shall do my deuoyre. And
when Florence herd yt she was not content in her mind, for she thought that
Arthur had been sore weary of that days journey, and thought that it should
greatly anoy him if he turnayed the next day and so she thought she would let
that journey y^ she might, tha^ she commanded the king her father to god as at
that time, than she took with her into her tent the archebyshop and diverse
others of her barons, and king Emendus caused Arthur to be brought into his
tent with all his hole baronye, and all the emperors knights spoke of no thing
but of Arthurs prowess, for they said that there was not again in all the
world so good a knight as he was beholding and considering al his deeds, and
how that he had borne him self in this turney, and the emperor said yt he
would rather resemble to him than to have such an other empire as his own
was: and the bruyte of Arthurs renown sprad so far abroad, till at last it
came to the hearing of sir Rowland, and than he said I thank god that such a
knight has Iusted agenst me, for my honor is the more Tha^ the king Emendus
came into his one tente, and than caused Arthur to come to him, and there were
all the other kings who did much honor to Arthur, and there were diverse that
said to the king of Soroloys, sir behold here this knight full of bounte and
worthy to have great honor, and all that they said by Arthur who as than was
right hor^. Than the king co^maunde^ two squyers to stand with a towell and
blow wynd into his face, and thus Arthur stood before the king and he was
goodly for to behold, for he was straight long and bygge, and above all other
right gracyous of his words, for every man had great disporte at his lowly and
goodly words. Than the king commanded yt there should be brought to Arthur a
mantell to cast on him to thentent he should take no could, and the king of
orqueney did put it about him, yt which became him right well. And than
th^re came to them Gouernar to whom there was made right great feast and joy,
there came thither the earl of ye isle perdue who^ Arthur had taken prisoner in
the tournay, and in his company.xxx. knights to pledge him of his ransom.
And the king made him right good chere. And sir Roulande and themperours
senesshall who had Iusted before with Arthur by that time were heled of their
hurtes, and were come also in to the kings tente to sport them and to here
tidings of the tournay. And wha^ the earl of the isle perdue saw them he had
great joy, and demanded of them how they did. And they answered and said
how that they had been sore hurt, but as than they were well amended. Than the
earl said to the king Sir it is of troth that I was taken in your tournay,
therefore sir I am come to you to be delivered of my ransom, therefore may it
please you to show me your pleasure, and I am ready to accomplis^he your
commau^deme^t. Certainly sir said the king it lies not in me, for that matter
lies in the pleasure of Arthur, who is here present who that took you
prisoner in ye field. Sir said Arthur saving your grace that is not so, for the
tornay is yours, and I am but as one of your knights and of my ladies your
daughter, therefore sir it were no reason that I should say or do any thing
where as your grace is present. In ye name of god said the king we will that ye
shall speak your mind, and it shall please us right well all yt ever ye shall
say or do. Than the king of valefou^de said, sir ye shall do thus, for it is
reason that ye do as my lord the king will have you. well sir said Arthur in
ye name of god, and so stood upon his fete and said to the king, sir and it
like your grace sith it is your pleasure yt I shall speak I say that this earl
here being present shall keep you company this dinner season, and after dinner
to sport and to play him with you as long as it shall please him, and when it
will please him to return to the emperor that he and all his company go
frank and free, and I will desire him to take of my gift this sword, the
which I think be good and sure, the which Gouernar had brought to him before
fro master Steven by the commandment of Florence to thente^t that he should
give it to the earl, and in deed there was not a better sword in all the
emperors host, and there Arthur desired the earl for his love to take it for
a remembrance, and also desired him to take a horse of his gift in recompense
of the horse yt he had taken fro him in the field. And when the king herd
Arthur have these words he had great joy, and loved him withal his heart
because of his gentilnes. Than therle answered and said, sir gentle knight of
heart I have richesse sufficient and am able to be set a right great rau^some
though it were.xx. or.xxx. duckettes, and also I have swe^des and horses
enough, how be it y^ hye prowess that is in you and the great gentylnes of
your heart provoke me to receive all your courtesye, and verily I take all
your offer of you on the condition that ye will fro hens forth take mi aid and
socours in all your busynes agenst al persons except my lord the emperor.
Than Arthur a^l smylyng thanked him much. Than the king enbraced the earl for
the love of Arthur, tha^ was water brought for^h an^ the king washed and the
earl and so dyned together and made good chere and were right richely served,
and after dinner they sported them togeth^r till it was time for the king to go
to his ^est. Than the earl took leave of the king and so commanded him to god.
And Arthur conuayed him a great ^pace, and did give to the earls knights many
good horses and palf^aies, whereof they thanked him right gretely. And at the
last A^thur ^oke his leave of him and so depa^ted, and than the earl went
straight to ye emperors tente where as he found him accompanied with the duke
of bygor and many other noble knights* and there the earl made grea^e praysyng
of Arthur before themperoure and showed how of his gentylnes he had suffered
him to go qu^te, and how that he had given him many gr^te gif^es, and also to
his knights. Uerely said the emperor there is not such a knight in all ye
world* neither of beautye nor of prowess, for he is the sovereign knight of al
other, for I s^ none like him of prowess, I would I had given ye best city
that I have on the condition that h^ were retained as my knight. And when ye
duke of bygor herd the emperor praise so much Arthur, he was in his mind right
sore displesed and said to therle, sir ye make here a great ple^yng of a flying
vacabond* for no man knows what he is, nor fro whens he comes, and ye make
of him here such a noise, that no man takes head of any thing else, I can
not tell you what he has given you, certainly it is no honor for you to take
any gifts of a man fugytyue that is fled or banysshed out of his own
country, but sir I will ye know certaynely yt what so ever gifts he has given
you, to morrow shall I give you his head from his sholders therefore I hold him
wise in that h^ has d^parted of his tresour in his life days to you and to
your company, for I waran^ him he shall do so never again. well sir said therle,
threte him hardely fair and easily that he knew it not, for and he do I fere
me lest that he will fly away, and than ye can not give me his head and sir
where as ye say that no man ^noweth what he is, sir I ensure you he is a right
noble wise knight, and it makes no matter to a noble knight where so ever he
becomes, for his boun^e will show right well his estate and where as ye say
that he is a vacabonde and is fled out of his own country, sir it had been
better to your neuew that he had fled into England or that he met with him
at ^^ge^ce, for there your neuewe lost his life, and there ye fled a way
without by doing of any farewell, he needs not to ^aue any care though ye say
thus of him for an ill tongue enpayreth ^euer the honor of a noble wise man,
and I en^ure you I will show him th^se vylayne words that ye say of him* and
if any ill come to you thereby take it a worth. Than ye duke began to wa^e
ang^y, and so the ma^er would have been worse and the emperor had not been, for he
caused them to be departed and to be in peace. Now let us leave to speak of
them, and return to Florence.

How that Florence feigned her self to be sick, to the intent that Arthur
should not tourney the next day, for she was in fere that Arthur had been
weary because of the travail that he had endured the first day of the
tournay. And how that the emperor when he knew that he went to se her, and
so did her fader king Emendus, and all other kings dukes earls and barons,
and all the hole chyualry. Capitulo. lxxx.
Emendus. Florence.


When that Florence was departed fro the king her fader and entered into her
tent, than she drew her into her secret chamber and called to her master
Steven and said. Fair sweet master I am right sore displeased in my heart
because yt the king my fader has desired my love Arthur to turnay again to
morrow in the company of the king of mormall, for I see well he does not
consider the travail that he has endured this day, for if he were made of
stele he ca^ not endure thus every day to travail, alas if any ill or
dishonor should come to him I should die for sorrow. I se well they yt thus
desire him to go forth again to morrow love but little his health, wherefore I
will find some means to put of the tournay as to morrow to thentente that he
shall be the more fresh the next day after, therefore I will send word to the
king my fader how that I am sick in my bed desyring him that as to morrow the
tournay may be deferred till the next day, but master I desire you let
Arthur have knowledge of the troth, for else I fere me he would be sorrowful
for my disease Madame said the master ye speak wisely and I shall tell you
why, first thereby Arthur shall well rest him, and secondly it is so he is as
now gre^ly praised of his courtesy, and is taken as chief companion with the
king your fader, and with all the other kings and barons, and as I understand
he is gretely in the grace of the emperor and of all his knights, for all
this hole assemble loue^h him, and as soon as the emperor hereth of your
disease he will come and se you accompanied with all the nobles of his company,
and when the king your fader hereth of his co^mi^g to you I doubt not but that
he and all his other.iiii. kings with all the noble men of their company will
in likewise come to se you so than thereby here shall be assembled all the hole
chyualrye, and so than at some hour conuenyent while they be al here it shall
be well done to assaye the virtue of the chaplet, and to se to whom the image
will give it ^o. Alas master I love this knight, and I would not for any
thing that an other should have it, and I fere me leest the image will give
it to some other person. Than the master all smiling said, madame what
perauenture and the image give me the chaplet would ye be content, and as he
spoke he smelled to a fair rose that he held in his hand. Master quod
Florence ye please me right well and I love you faithfully, and also I ^o.
Arthur. Madame said yt master than sith I please you and that ye love me and
Arthur also, than it makes no matter wheder that I or he have the chaplet since
that your love is on us both. Ye but mayst^r said Florence, in my love there is
a dyfference. And what is ye difference I pray you madame show me the troth
Truly master that rose that ye hold in your hand right well does sygnyfy
it. This rose madame said the master and I pray you how. Harken master to me
and I sh^l show you, it is so I se in that rose three manner of things, first
the closoure without the which keeps fro hurting the budde till it be a full
rose spradde abroad, and when it is spradde than the leaves be fair and read,
and in the mids of the rose there little grains resembling to gold, and out
of this rose there may be felt such odor and smell that it perseth
throughout the nose eue^ to the heart for the heart will rejoice with the good
sm^ll thereof. In the name of god said the mayst^r all this that ye say is
true, but madame what does all this sygnifye. Master said Florence I shall
show you the closure without the which keeps ye budde fro hur^ing til it be
sprede abroad sygnyfyeth you, who has kept me till this day without
enpayryng, for it is now time that the rose sprede abroad that is to say to
mary me and to keep my land as it pertains to the daughter of a king, and
these leaves of the rose that be so fair and read, signifies your troth and
faythfulnes, for I have found ever i^ you great troth and bou^te toward me
and also to my fader and to all the hole realm, and master in this rose there
be grains like unto gold, the which is the precoyust metal of all the world,
and that is sygnifyed by the great and excellent clergy that is in you the
which is more precious than gold, for thereby ye have always kept and defended
me in all my needs, and master by these.iii. points I love you But the fourth
thing that is in this rose is the sweet ^auour thereof, the which perseth all the
hole body even to the heart, for in the flagrau^t odor thereof both the body
and the heart is reioysed, and certainly master this.iiii. love that comes
thus of this rose is min own love Arthur who is chief rose, and above all other
most fair, and above all other knights most valiant, as the rose is chief
of all flowers. Madame said the master I se well ye have had a good and a sage
master, and I se well how that ye love me well with out, but ye love Arthur
inwardly, and by my soul ye can not do better, for ye can have none better
than he is, and know ye for certain that none shall have you but all only he.
Gentyl master said Florence help me thereto, for all my trust is in you. Madame
as I understand he is come into the senesshalles tent. well master than go
your way to him and show him that I will that he come and se me, and bring
with him the senesshal and such other company as he will, and than shall I se by
their countenance if they be content though I make Arthur a little good and
lowly semblau^t, for oftentimes the will of the heart shows it self fayrely
outward, for it is hard to know an other man's will without there be made to
him some manner of semblau^t whereby he shall have occasyon to utter somewhat of
his will. Madame said the master I se well it is a subtle thing of a woman's
wit when they li^t them self, than the master rose and went into the
senesshalles tent. At which time Brisebar said, here lacks none now in this
company but the master. And with that word he entered in at the door. And than
sir Miles said, loo syrs when one speaks of the wolf lightly he sees his
tail* and so therwt they welcomed the master, and caused him to sit down by
Arthur. Than the master said to Arthur, sir how have ye done in this tournay,
how seems you by the knights of this country, be they not as valiant as the
knights of france. Certainly master said Arthur they be as valiant and
rather more hardy, for there is none yt I have seen but yt they ought right
well to be received in to the hye order of chyualry. Sir said the master ye
may not depart fro hens now till ye se my lady Florence, for and ye do she will
not be content. Master said Arthur in the name of god I would right glad to se
her, but I know not her pleasure in yt behalf, let us goo and se her all
together, and so they rose and went all together with Arthur, and the master
went in before the Florence and said. Madame behold here is Arthur who is
come to se you. He is right welcome said Florence, and so she rose against him,
and the queen of orqueney took Arthur by the hand and set him down by her and
she demanded of him how that he did sith the tournay. And he answered her
how that he did right well. By the good lord said Florence in the tournay ye
suffered much pain and travail, and right well there ye did, wherefore your
lover if ye have any ought to love you the better and this she said al smyling
and laid her hand upon his heed. Madame as god help me said Arthur I have
not as much love as I would have. In good faith said the queen of Orqueney if
she were right hye and noble she should be right well enployed on you. Ye truly
said Brisebar I would he were beloved as well as I would according to my will,
and when Florence herd yt she smyled and said, sir Brysebar by the faith yt
ye owe unto the hye order of chyualry and to saint George what is your will in
that case. Madame said he I will not show that, for peraue^ture it should
displease you. Nay by my soul said Florence I will not be displeased what so
every say, therefore show me your mind, also I command you so to do.
Madame sith it is your pleasure I shall show you, I would yt ye loved him in
such wise that he were your lord and husbonde, for a more sweter, courteyser,
nor a better knight can ye not have again in all the world, for a more gentle
gracious co^pani coud not be found again as should be of you twain. well
Brisebar said Florence and say ye this with good heart. Ye truly madame by all
the saints of paradyse. well sir senesshall said Florence and what should be
your mind. Madame said he I pray to god I never go out of this place but I
would it were so on the co^dit^o^ that it cost me as much as I am worth. Tha^
she demanded the same of all other, and they al with one voice said ye same. well
syrs said she behold well wheder ye have wysshed your profit in this or not,
for ye al know well how that this emperor demau^deth me of ye king my fader
and would have me to his wife, and therefore if it were so that an other took me
he would have great despyte and move against him war, whereby should ensue that
al ye should be put ^o pain and trouble, and in peril of your ly^es, for ye
be al my men wherefore ye ought to defend me against all mine enemies. Madame
said Brisebar by my soul I care not for that against who so ever it be, and it
be not against my lord your fader, for if Arthur might be ever among us we
need not to care for all the world nor any manner of pain yt I should suffer for
his sake should never grieve me. well than quod Florence I se well yt ye would
suffer pain and peril of your body on the condition yt I would have him to my
husbonde, and than she demanded so of all the other knights if they would in
like wise. And they answered yes all with one voice. And how should I be sure of
this said Florence. Madame said they all we faithfully assure you by the faith
of our bodies and lesynge of our lands and goods. Than Florence said to
Arthur, sir ye have here many good fre^des. Madame said he I thank them and
god reward them, and I shall deserve it to them when I may. By my faith quod
the master I believe you well, for ye have a large and a plenteous heart, and so
therewith Florence brake their words of y^ matter, and fell in communication of
other matters til it was time to depart. Than Arthur took his leave of Florence
and of all other* and master Steven conuaied him forth and said to him in his
ere, sir be not trobled in your mind though as to morrow yt ye here y^ my lady
Florence be somewhat diseased* for she will do it for such causes as ye shall
know right well here after. well quod Arthur I am and ever shall be content with
her noble pleasure, and so than ye master took his leave of Arthur and
returned again to Florence, and Arthur went straight to the king of orqueneys
tent, and than they both went together to the king Emendus te^t who as than was
rysynge fro sleep, and so they three sat down together and talked of many
things till it was time to goo to their souper, where as they were rychely
served, and after souper they sported them together till it was time to goo to
their restes. Than the king departed and al other for that night.

How the tournay the next day was deferred because of Florence disease.
Capitulo. lxxxi.
IN the next morning betymes the master rose and lept on his horse, and so in
great haste rode straight to ye kings te^t, and there he did alight, and so
was brought to the kings beds side. And when the king saw him there so erly
he demanded what tidinges* Certainly sir said the master my lady Florence
has been this night right sore seek, and is as yet right sore holden with the
collyke in her body, therefore sir she desires your grace that ye tournay this
day may be deferred till to morrow by which time she trusts to be well amended
so yt she will come and se the tournay if god will se^de her any ease of her
pain. Saint mary said the king gentyl master has she than such pain, I
should be right sorry if she should fortune to dye as God forbid without any
issue of her body, for I will never have wife, nor I have no mo children but
she, wherefore than the realm of Sorolois should be without heir of the right
stock the which should be a great damage to all this realm, I think verily
she had to great hete yesterday ye beholding of y^ tournay. Sir said ye master
with gods love she shall amend to morrow, but in good faith sir it were time
that she were well married, well master said the king I shall think thereof right
shortly. In the name of god sir quod ye master it is time yt I return to my
ladi, but sir for gods sake defer ye tournay til the next day because of
Florence sekenes Than the emperor sent a knight of his to Florence to know what
malady she had, but Florence had commanded tha^ if any body came fro
the emperor yt he should not be suffered to enter into her tente, so thereby ye
knight could not be suffered to enter and so returned again to the emperor and
showed him how yt no body could enter into her tent to speak with her, and than
the emperor said well I will go se her my self, than all the kings, dukes,
earls* and barons yt were in his company mounted on their horses and rode forth
with the emperor And when the king Eme^dus herd that the emperor was ridynge to go
se Florence his daughter, than he mounted on his horse and al his kings and
knights with him, and when they were al met and assembled together there was so
much people as though all the world had been there, and at last a messenger
came to master Steue^ and said, sir the emperor and the king and al other noble
men yt be in this field are coming to se my lady Florence. Than ye master went
and did show that to her. Tha^ she commanded that there should be made ready a
rich bed before her pauilyo^ right before ye face of the image with ye chaplet,
and the image was properly besene with a kyrtyl of purpel ^atyn and a gown of
grene sarcenet, and upon the bed there was a rich quylt wrought with coten
covered with crimsen sendal stytched with thredes of gold, and shetes of white
sylke, and over al a rych furre of ermynes, this bed was right rich, and
Florence laid her down in her bed in a light kyrtell of chaungeable vyolet
tartorne some what blusshynge on a red color, and she had a keuerchefe of
white sylke on her head all loose untied wherefore there might be seen under the
keuerchefe her fair throat as white as yuery, and her fair golden heir
flying about her neck and her fair face was in a mean neither to long nor to
ro^nde fresshely colored like the rose on the lylly, and on her there was a
cast ma^tell of grene silk and she did cast out her arms thereon, so that her
white hands and her long fyngers were stretched abroad on the mantel and the
queen of orqueney sat by her who said to the master, sir make your self
now as though ye were dyspleased because that my lady is sick. That is well
said quod the master, and so shall I do, therewith he rusht togider his hat and
made semblaunt as though he had been very angry, whereat the queen and Florence
did smy^e right swetly. By y^ time the emperor and all the kings and knights
were come, than the emperor went on the one side of the bed and the king her
father on the other side, and so sat them down on the sides of the bed, and
all the other lords and knights stood round about ye bed. Than there came
also the king of orqueny and Arthur with him, and they len^e them down on the
beds fete. Than the emperor did salute Florence, and she said how yt he was
welcome. Than the king her father d^maunded of her how she did, and laid his
hand on her head. Tha^ she beheld her father and said, sir I have been this
night and al morning right ill at ease, but thanked be god I do now better
than I did. God be thanked said the king. Than the king of orqueney who was
right preuy of her counsel said. Madame think not long, for with gods leave
ye shall soon be hole. And than she beheld him and smyled a little and said,
sir I would be glad thereof* and so thus they talked together of one thing and
other a great space. And Florence said how yt their company did her much
good.

How the image in the pauylyon did set ^er chaplet on Arthurs head in ye
presence of the emperor and of.x. other kings and of all the hole assembly,
wherwyth the emperor was right sorrowful because he thought to have had
Florence in marriage, but he failed of his purpose, for the image took no regard
neither to the emperor nor to none other there, but al only to Arthur to
whom freely she did give her chaplet. Capitu. lxxxii.
ANd when the master saw his time and knew how yt all ye hole barony were
there assembl^d he rose upon his fete and said in open audience. Mine own dear
and redoubted lady Florence our lord god has done you this day great grace
and honor, for I believe verily yt never before this time there were never so
many noble men assembled together as be now here present for to se a lady yt
is dyseased, for madame ye may se here about your bed an emperor.x. kings
dukes and earls mo than.l. and al ye hole barony of thempyre of ynde the more,
and also of.x other kingdoms, wherefore madam ye ought to be right joyous and
more at ease in your heart* for they al love you and are glad you to plese, and
also as I understand my lord the king your father has great will if god be
pleased to puruey for you a right hye and a noble marriage* and I think yt if
it plese him now in his mind may be well satysfyed, for I believe he shall never

present, wherefore now he may fulfill his pleasure, and according to my mind it
were time that ye were married Than Florence sat her up in her bed and a lady

much that he is now well at the point thereof if it be his pleasure, but it is

such destenyes as were destenyed of me at my natiuytye, and because that
paraduentur^ all ye my lords yt be here present at this time knows not what
it is yt was destenyed on me, therefore I shall show it here in open ^udyence.
It is of troth that my lady my mother whom god assail when I was borne s^e
sent me by ye king of Orqueney and mine ^ncle tharchbysshop and by the queen
of orqueney who are al here present, to the mount of adventures, and there it

I pray to god he do so that it may be for ye best. Than tharchbisshop rose and

present and both saw and herd al this that she has said, for as god help me

not presume to have her for all the good of the world, with out so be I had first
the chaplet. Than ye king of valefound rose and said, according to my mind it

other till it be given to one or to other. In the name of god said the king

How that Proserpyne queen of ye fayry who rese^bled to Florence laid her

When the king of orqueney ^ tharchebyshop were departed fro ye king Emendus
and saw^ how y^ the king had granted Florence his daughter to the emperor,
they went^ straight to Florence where as they found Arthur, duke Phylyp, and
Gouernar and they were all still armed to thentent to defend them if any need
were. Than the king of orqueney caused them to be unarmed and took Arthur by
the hand^ and said, sir as long as I live and have any land I shall not fail
you, but I shall aid you to dye in the quarrel to defend your right. Sir
said Arthur god tha^ all thing fourmed keep you and reward your gentylnes.
Go we quod the king and speak with Florence, and so they went to her, and as
than she was still sitting on her bed all afraid of the bronte and fraye
that was there, and the Queen of orqueney sat weeping for f^re of ye king her
husband. Than there sat down the king, tharchebysshop, Arthur, and Gouernar,
and also there was the master and duke Phylyp. Than the king said to
Florence, madame be ye in peace and rest and doubt ye of nothing, but it is
so my lord the king your fader has given you to the emperor, and has put
him in possession of you by the glove of his hand, and all the other kings are
of his accord, but tharchebysshop your uncle and I are departed fro them
because we will not consent thereto in no wise, therefore madame may it please
you now to show us your mind wheder ye be content to have him to your
husbo^de or not for if it please you it behooves us to be content, and if it
please you not to have him here I offer my self to you that or he have you
against your will I shall rather adventure to lose my heed from the shoulders,
and I shall put in ieopardy to slay the emperor in defending of this gentylman
Arthur in his right if ye be so content. And when Florence herd him say so
she began right sore to weep, and when she might speak she said, a gentyl king
now I se well I have no mo friends but you and such other as be here present,
alas I am of ye estate that I ought of right to have many mo, but when my fader
and mine own men fail me, alas to whom shall I compain me, alas unkind
fader will ye give me him whom that I hate mortally, and take fro me him that
I love faithfully, and therewith her heart was so oppressed with bitter sorrow
that she fell on so sore a weping that it was great pity to behold her, and
when she might somewhat speak she said, certainly I had rather dye than to have
the emperor, and as God help me ye be all my friends and so I will retain you
as long as the world serves me, the which yet somewhat comforts me,
whe^fore I will no longer hyde my heart fro you, and so she turned her self
toward Arthur and said, behold here him who has my chaplet my dest^ny is on
him, wherefore I will have none other but him* for him I love and will do. And
wha^ the king of orqueney herd her say so he had great joy and said,
madame we be all your own men and friends and of your counsel and would
always your honor and profit, and as God help me ye can not do better than
to set your heart on this noble knight Arthur, for better: more wise more
goodlyer ^ha^ he is ca^ not be found, and sith it pleases you as for my part
I am the same accord, and to him I offer now my self here present, now let
all other speak every man for him self. Tha^ the archebysshop said, fair
lady ye are my nece and I am your uncle, in good faith I am agreed to your
pleasure, and I promise him faith and troth, and to aid him against all

and said, madame I am your clerk and always I trust I have counsayled you to

to garnysshe the house withal for the space of.vii. year, and they had xxvii.
charyottes continually carieng.vii. wekes together of such stuff as pertayned

sufficient for the space of.vii. year.

How that the lady Margaret of Argenton with all her hole barony went and
met Florence and received her in to Argence with right great feast and joy.
Ca. lxxxiiii.
ANd the third day after that Florence knights were departed fro her, tha^ she
and the queen of orqueney and tharchebysshop departed and went first to the
cite of pancopone the which pertained to the bishop and there he commanded al
his people to be ready on a day warning in their best apparaile for the war,
and in likewise did Gouernar in the realm of blau^che toure, so than Florence
departed fro pancopone and went straight to Argence. And as soon as the lady
Margarete had knowledge that she was two days journey fro Arge^ce she mounted
on her horse and.v.C. in her company and went and encountered the lady Florence
of Soroloys, and when she met her she did right humbly salute her and said*
Madame ye be right hertely welcome in to this country, and madame behold me
here who is and shall be your humble damoysel ever to be ready at your noble
commandment. Certainly fair lady Magarete said Florence I take you and will
do for my special friend and faithful lover. Than ye lady Margarete went to
the bishop and to duke Phylip and right swetely did salute them, and than she
demanded of Florence how it was with Arthur. And she answered and said: fair
lady Margarete he is abyden in the court with the king of orqueney and with
master Steven. And I pray you madame how does he. Verily said she right well.
Than am I glad said the lady Margarete, for Arthur is my lord and chief fader:
for he has re^dred again to me my land whereof I was dysheryted by the neuew
of the duke of bigor. well said Florence care not for yt for ye be as now well
revenged both of the uncle and of the neuewe. A madame said she blessed be them
that has brought that about, and thus they rode forth on their way and they
encou^tred sir Miles and sir Artaude and diverse other knights pertaining to
Florence, and al other knights of that country drew thither by great flocks,
and wha^ they were nere to the cite of Argens, than there issued out of all the
honest burgeises of the cite riding on good horses, and fair faucons and
sparhawkes on their fistes and they were well to the nombre of fifty well arrayed
al in one suit half scarlet and half grene, with many tabours and trompettes
before th^ym. Than the bishop saw well how that the cite of Argence was right
noble and goodly, for he saw ye bright son glimmering on ye fair chirches
and hye steples covered al with fair led, and also he saw the rich baners
and stremers pyght out of wyndowes of the fair houses, and the batylmentes
were pyght full of sheldes, basenettes, helmes and speres to thentent to show
ye strength of the cite, and the streets were hanged with clothes of gold and
of silk, and with read sendall chaungeable with grene and all the helles of
the town sole^pny did ring so that it was great joy to se and to behold the
noblenes of that cite. In this manner Florence entered in to the cite, having in
her company beyond.xv. hundred knights, and the burgeyses of the cite mounted
up into their windows to behold Florence who was led between the bishop and
duke Phylip, and thus they rode til they came to the palace, and there descended
and so mounted up into yt hal than Florence entered into her chamber and
apparayled her, and by that time her diner was ready and the tables ready
covered, than Florence and the archebisshop and all other sat them down to
dinner and were right tychely served, and so there Florence soiourned the space
of.viii. days. Now let us leave Florence at Argence and return to the emperor
and to king Emendus and to Proserpyne who was ^ayde in Florence bed in the
stead of her.

How that Proserpyne was ensured to the emperor in the stead of Florence, and
how that the king banysshed out of his country the king of orqueney, and also
she king of valefounde and master Steven and Arthur. Capitulo.lxxxv.
SO it was that wha^ Florence was departed fro ye court of king Emendus her
fader and that he had given her to the Emperor, tha^ each of them went into
their own tents to diner, and the king of Orqueney wh^ was abiden still in
Florence tente with Proserpyne queen of the fayry who resembled so nere
Florence that the one could not be known fro the other, and there he and Arthur
dined with her, and after dinner the emperor came to king Eme^dus and said, sir ye
have given me Florence daughter, and sir I know well how that the king or
orqueney and Arthur be still with her in her tent, and they have been always
contrary to me, wherefore I doubt me leest they (...) Florence mind fro
mewarde, therefore sir I pray you let us go and fiau^ce her this night and let
us be married to morrow. Sir said the king I am content, and I promise you yt al
such who so ever they be yt be contrary against your mind shall incontinent
forsake my company, than the emperor and the king and the other three kings went
straight to Florence te^t, and as soon as they were entered the king of orqueney
and the master and Arthur rose and welcomed them, than the king sat him down
on the one side of the bed and the emperor on the other side than the king
said to Proserpyne wenynge to him it had been his daughter Florence, fair
daughter it behooves you to be fiaunced this night to this emperor and to
morrow ye shall be wedded with great joy* well said sir Proserpyne sith it is your
pleasure I am content let it be done inconty^ent, than the king demanded for
tharchebyshop his brother to the^tent to ensure them togider Sir said the
master he is gone to pancopone for abesynes yt he has to do there and duke
Phylyp also. And where is Florence senesshall and al other knights. Sir surely
they been al gone with him. In the name of god sir said the emperor the
archebisshop has been always contrary to me in yt I should have Florence,
therefore sir never trust me but yt he is gone to do some manor of ^reason to
the intent yt I should not have her. Than stepped forth ye master and said, sir
emperor ye say no^ wisely to call the archebysshop traitor or to say yt he
seeks to work any treason against you it is to largely said, for there was
never as yet any noble man of S^roloys that ever did any treason against you or
against any other man living and though that he be not of the accord of this
marriage he does but right, for saving the honor of my lord the king here
present all that be of that accord are forsworn and have broken their promesses
and couenau^tes and does against their own seals, and as for me as long as I
live shall I never accord thereto. No master said the king will ye not than
accord thereto, but hold all other forsworn, by the faith that I owe unto god
if ye were not the son of a king I should make you well to know how ye have
spoken folishely here in my presence, but thus much I say unto you I charge you
incontinent that ye avoid this pauylyon, and I defend you the coming again
to my syghte, and dyscharge you out of Florence counsel. well sir said the
master sith I se than that I must needs leave your court and coming before
you and banysshed fro ye counsel of my lady for this emperor here present,
wherefore let him be in certain yt as long as I live he shall never put ringe
on my lady Florence finger nor wedde her for all the power yt he has or can
have. Than the king was sore dyspleased and rose and had thought to have
stricken the master, but the king of mormal and the king of Ismaelyte did
hold him, and therewith the master went out of the pauylyon. And when the
king of valefounde saw his sone cast out of the court and how the king would
have stryken him he rose up and said to the king, sir for the esche wyng of
all ill and trouble before this time I was agreed that this emperor should
have your daughter, wherein now I confess me yt I was forsworn and did therein
contrary to mine own seal and promise, the which consentement now here I
openly revoke and deny, for as god help me I will be no longer forsworn,
therefore I say to this emperor yt he take her not, for if he do let him be in
certain that there is and shall be in the realm of va^^^ounde a king who is not
his friend, but he is and shall be his mortal enemy. And when king Emendus
herd him speak in ye manner he was right sore dyspleased, for he loved and
bileued him right well before and said, sir king either consent to this
marriage or else forsake the presence of me and shortly avoid this pauylyon.
well sir than I will depart, and I warraunt you I will no more desire to come
in to your sight, I say no more but god give grace ye do well, and therewith he
went out of the pauylyon and went to his son master Steue^. Than the king of
orqueney rose up and said to the king, sir I have great marvel where ye have
taken this counseyle to enstrau^ge your self fro your friends and counseyllers,
verily sir ye be in an ill mind in this case and al for this emperor who

well sir said the king of orqueney care not for y^ matter, for I ensure you he
shall not wedde her this year. Sir said he it can be none other wise, for

emperor and king so abused and abashed as they shall be. In the name of god

hardy a knight in all his company but he shall be aferde to gyrde his sword

they will needs make war agenst you do to this emperor as much damage as

and wisely said, I am agreed let it be done as ye have said As god help me

Syrs I ^hanke ^ou said Florence, so than they est^^^isshed Arthur chief

How that Proserpyn queen of the fairy was led to the church to have been
wedded to themperoure wenyng that it had been Florence, but when the bishop
had thought to have put the weddyng ring on her finger, suddenly she
vanysshed away, so that none wist whether she became, and so than they stood
all abashed as though the clouds had fallen from heaven. Capi. lxxxvi.
SO it was that when the king of valefound and the king of Orqueney was
departed fro king Emendus to great displesure how be it the king as than when
he saw that they were gone he repented him of his folly, how be it he made no
manner of semblau^t for the love of the emperor, but said to him, sir let us go
to the city of cornyte and there shall ye fyaunce Florence, and to morrow be
married to her. Sir with a right good will said the emperor. Than Proserpin was

of mormal and the king of Ismaelye did led her to church, and as (...) she

Of the king of Orqueney and of the king of va^e^ound can ye show me any word

what counsel and remedy shall we make for this knight Arthur who has thus

king the castle doubts no man, but I allow w^ll let us besiege the castle

And there shall ye find me also said the king Than the emperor commanded to

How that Arthur sent Gouernar to his cosyn Hector duke of orgoule desiringe
him to come and help to socour him agenst the emperor of ynde, and agenst the
king Emendus, who would besiege him in the castle of ye port noyre, Ca. lxxxvii.
SO it was that when the king of orqueney and the king of valefound were
departed from Arthur out of the port noyre as ye have heard here before, than
wtin a little space after there came to Arthur a spy streyghte fro Cornyte,
and there he recounted to Arthur all the delyng of the emperor and of king
Eme^dus and how that they somon together great people to come to assyege them
at the port noyre. And when Arthur herd that he said to duke Philip, well sir
than there is no more to do but let every man do the best they can, wherefore
it is time that ye send to sabary to your senesshall that he bring hither to
you al your chyualry now at this Ester and ye my lady Florence send forth your
letter to your relame of blau^che toure, and let my lady Margaret send to
Argence, and I shall send to orgoule to my cousin Hector. why than said Florence
have ye than a cousin in these parts. Ye madame by the faith that I owe to your
grace, for if I might have him ones by my side* doubt but little the malice of
this emetoute, than she made her lettes and se^e sir Neuelon to the clear
toure, and so ^parted. And when he was there aryue^non he found sir Perdycas
who was these gouernar of all that realm of clear owre, and to him he

will abide and look me in the face. Than the countess said, fair son I

sent into all the duchye of Orgoule to sir Clarembalt that he should assemble
