How that Hector as he went toward the port noyre to socoure Arthur, he
encountered one of the kings that was coming toward themperoure, and had in
his company well unto the nombre of xviii. thousand men of wa^^e the which
king Hector slew and all his people, so that there was none that ever escaped
saving two, and so they fled away, and there Hector was a great botye and
much treasure and great habou^dau^c^ of vytayle the which was al brought in to
the port noyre. Capi. lxxxviii.


THus as Hector and his people were entered into this great valley they
perceived where as there came to themwarde about the nombre of.xviii.
thousand men of war. Than Hector demanded of Gouernar if that he knew them.
And he answered and said sir nay in good faith, but I doubt me least they be of
our enemies. Than Hector made al his host to be armed, and he him self and
Gouernar armed them, and when they were armed Gouernar presed forth and
demanded one of them fro whence they were. And one of them answered and said,
friend it is king Godyfer who is going toward the emperor to help him to
lay siege to the port noyre to the intent to take it and to slay a knight that
is therein, who has taken away Florence daughter to king Emendus the which lady
should have been wedded to my lord the emperor, wherefore there is none that is in
that castle or takes part with that knight but that the shall dye all a shame
full death, what said Gouernar tha^ thou do threten me and yet thou call
me friend, but I shall quite yt for thy labor therefore defend thy self. than
Gouernar drew his sword and struck so the knight between the sholders and
the neck that he claue him down to the waste, and than Gouernar said I trow
I have assured this knighte to be on our part, for I think he will abide here
still in this place. Tha^ said Hector I se well that between Gouernar and this
knighte there was but little friendship, than Hector be held and saw where king
Godyfer did desryng him self to come on Gouernar as fast as he might, but
Hector met him first and struck the king so rudelye that he overthrew him wide
open in the feld than Hector turned him with his sword in his hand to have
stryken of his head but his people socoured him and ran on Hector on all sides,
but Hector struck so among them that he brake the great prese than Gouernar
dashte into the thyckest of the prese without sparyng of any body, for he cut
of arms legs and hedes great p^enty. Than sir Clatembart entered into the
prese, and sir Oaths in like wise, than there began such a fray that it was
pity to behold, than king Godyfer was remounted again and Hector laid on
round about him, and he went so much forward that he was closed in among his
enemis, how be it he gave among them so great strokes that all yt ever he
attained unto went to the death but his enemis did cast at him knyues and
dagers, so that at the last therbi they slew his horse under him, than he lept
on his fete with his sword in his hand but his enemies oppressed him gretely.
Therewith Gouernar came to him all in a great rage, and he was also at his coming
so beset with his enemies that his horse was slain under him and than Hector
and Gouernar were in that case yt it was hard for them to escape, till at
last sir Clarembalt and al his rou^e came to them and so than there began so
sore a battle that it was wonder to behold, and than Hector and Gouernar did
so valiantly that each of them gate him a new horse and so in the spyte of
all their enemies they were again remounted, and than they dashed into the
prese and gave so mighty strokes that they confounded all that ever they
attained unto, than the king Godyfer came on them with so great a prese that
they drew by clean force Gouernar and sir Oaths out of the prese and closed
them so round about, and gave them so many great strokes yt they slew their
horses under them, and than they defended them self as valiaunte knights
ought to do, and oftentimes they called for Hector to help to rescowe them,
but the prese was so great and thycke yt Hector in no wise could get to them
and yet there he did maruailes with his hands, for he all to frusshed sheldes
and vnbarred helmes and ket down knights but Gouernar and sir oaths were so
over laden that they were both taken prysone^s and led out of the battle.
Than Gouernar said, a dear master Arthur to god I you commend, he that al
thing fourmed keep and save thy noble body. But when Hector knew that they
were taken prisoners he was so sore displeased that nigh he enraged for sorrow,
and so habandoned him self among his enemies and gave so great and heavy
strokes that every man fled before him, for he struck none but that they lost
their lives, or else sore wounded. And in the mean season Gouernar and sir
Oaths were led forth toward the emperor who was coming after, and as they were
thus led forth they met with sir Brysebar and Clemenson senesshal to duke
Phylyp of sabary, and Brysebar knew Gouernar as soon as he saw him, than
Brysebar escryed and said, saint mary save Arthur the good knight, for I se well
that Gouernar is taken, therefore gentle knight help to socoure these two
knights who are pertayninge to the gentle Arthur, than all his company set
fyersly on them, and within a little while they were all slain and hewn in
small pieces, and than Gouernar and sir Oaths were remou^ted again and they said
to sir Brysebar. A sir for gods sake haste you as fast as ye can, for ye shall
find here before in a great valey the noble Hector cousin to Arthur fighting
with king Godifer who has with him a great company, wherefore I fere me
gretely that this noble duke Hector has to much in hand easily to escape.
Saint mary said Clemenson yonder I se them, Brysebar follow me, than they all
together in a front went together as fast as they might, and they were all
well to the nombre of.xx. thousand fyghting m^nne, than Clemenson dashed in to
the prese with his swerd in his hand, than he struck the first that he
encountered in such wise that he made his heed to fly fro his sholdres, and
sir Brisebar met so with an other that he claue his heed to his tethe, and
they did so much at their coming that they two bette down and slew mo
than.xx. knights. And when Hector saw that he said, saint mari what knights
be these or fro whens are they come. Than Gouernar who the same time came into
the prese answered Hector and said, sir I trust that I have ^one so much that
ye shall have noble socour, and when Hector saw Gouernar his heart reioysed
and said, friend help to socour yonder two knights, for they are worthy to
have help. Than by that time all the hole company of.xx. thousand was come in
to the prese, and there they flew knights great plente, so that all king
Godyfers company were nigh dyscomfyted. And when the king saw that he was so
sore dyspleased that nigh he was dead for anger, than he dashed his spor^s to his
horse and gave Hector such a stroke that he struck away of his shield and
harneys a great quarter, but as god would ye stroke did not enter into the
flesh, and Hector struck the king so rudely on the helm that he claue his
heed down to the sholdres, and therewith he fell down to the earth struck deed,
and when his people saw that they turned and fled away, but Clemenson and
Brisebar followed in the chase so that of.xviii. thousand they left on line but
two persons. Than Hector and Gouernar came to Clemenson and Brisebar and each
of them saluted other and Hector thanked them of their good socour. Than they
went all to the chari^ttes and carts that king Godyfer had bro^ght thither,
wherein they found great plente of gold and silver and great plente of
vitayle, the which Hector caused to be co^uaied to the port noyre. Than
Gouernar said to Hector, sir I will goo before to my lord Arthur and show him
of your coming, and come you after fair and easily. w^l said Hector go your
way in the name of god, and so he departed and went to the port noyre and
mounted up in to the palace, and there he found Arthur with Florence and the
bishop and master Steven and duke Phylyp. And when Arthur and duke Philyp
saw Gouernar they saw well by his harneys yt he had been in some bataile. Tha^
Arthur demanded of him what tidinges. Sir said he right good thanked be God,
sir behold yonder comes your cousin Hector and al his host who has
discomfyted and slain the king Godyfer, and of.xviii. thousand that he
brought with him there is left a live but two persons, with the which king we
met in a fair valey, and he was coming toward the emperor to have helped
him to have destroyed you, in the which fraye I was taken prisoner and also
the countess of Brules senesshal sir Oaths, but thanked be god and duke Phylyp
for his senesshall the gentle Clemenson and sir Brysebar did rescowe and
deliver us, so now the king Godyfer is slain and all his company, and Hector
brings with him great plente of gold and silver and vytayle the which he wan
in this batale, I know well it mounteth to the nombre of.ii.C. charyottes and
carts. A good lord said Arthur ye vytayle is more welcome than gold or
silver. Than by ye time Hector, Clemenson, and Brisebar alyghted at the port
noyre, and lodged all their host about in the castle, tha^ Arthur ran and
enbraced Hector al armed as he was and said, cosyn ye be right hertely welcome
to the helping of the noble Florence here present. Truly said Florence blyssed
be ye neighbor yt is ready to help at need, but Arthur how is it yt ye have
had such a kynnesma^ so nere us and would never show it to me. Madame quod
Arthur I did it for none ill intent, so tha^ Hector was led into a chamber to
be unarmed, and duke Philyp received Clemenson and Brysebar and sir Oaths with
great joy, and wha^ Hector was unarmed than he went into the palace, and
Florence beheld him and liked him wondersly, for she saw well that he was bygge
and well made, than she said to Arthur, sir this gentylman seems well to be of
a redoubted lynage. Sir quod the bishop he seems well to be of the valor of a
noble man. Ye sir quod Hector yt I warraunt you if I were at a table fair
covered with mete and drink thereon. As god help me said duke Philip he says
well for it were now time to ete some mete. Tha^ squyers set up tables, and in
ye mean time Florence and Arthur, duke Philip and the archebysshop went and
lent out at a window and at last they saw where there was coming Florence
senesshal and sir Perdicas and.xxx.M. in their company of Florence retinue, and
they al followed ye white baner of the realm of blau^che toure, than Florence
said to Arthur, sir behold yonder comes our folk yt shall help our
neighbors. Madame quod Arthur they be welcome, tha^ also they saw where there
came sir Miles and sir Emery and.xv.M. in their company, than the fair lady
Margarete said, madame behold yonder comes my copany, who are come to help
you at al times Margarete my love I thank you quod Florence of your good aid,
and god give me grace so long to live yt I may deserve it unto you. And wha^
Hector saw so many sta^dardes and stremers coming he said as god help me if
this were the emperor to this comi^g I would tha^ have trust soon to se him and
by ye good lord I shall se him as shortly as I can. So tha^ these knights did
alight and mounted up in to the palace, and Gouernar and Brisebar appointed
every man to his lodging, and these knights were received with great joy, and
they went to diner and were served right rychely with all manner of deyntees.

How that the emperor of ynde and the king Eme^dus accompanied with.viii.
kings, and well to the nombre of.iii.C.M men of war laid syege about the
castle of the port noyre where as Florence and Arthur were, whereof ill turned
to the emperor, for there he lost three of his kings and well an hundred
thousand of his men. Capitulo. lxxxix.


AFter dyuer wha^ all the tables were taken away, than Florence and the bishop
and Arthur went together and lened out at a window, and duke Phylip and the
master and Hector lened out at an other window, tha^ they saw whereas the king
of Mormall and the king of Ismaelyte with al their powers took their lodging and
pight their field about the castle, and the king Eme^dus was at Argence
abiding for the king of valefou^de and the king of orqueney, and wha^ they were
come to him than the king Emendus made his own peace with them, and made them a
large amendus in that he had before banysshed them his court and said how
that he did it but in a haste, and than repented him of his so delynge, and
when they were thus accorded than they all together set forth in their way toward
the port noyre, and the two kings went before, and the king with the great
dragon of Sorolois came in the rerewarde with al his host, so that all the
country was over spradde with people. Now I se well said Arthur that we shall
have war, but by the faith that I owe unto god if I may ones meddle with them
they shall not all return again. By the good lord said Hector they lodge
very nigh us, and yet they be not our fre^des. Than of the^perours company there
came king Jonas, and after him there came king Clamados, and than after came
the emperor him self, and he was right sorrowful when he knew of the death of
king Godifer and of his company, and how that all the tresour and vitaile was
taken into the port noyre, and so the emperor was lodged on the left side of
the castle. Than F^orence said to the bishop, sir how say ye is not yonder
people sufficye^t to take a lady prisoner. Certainly madame quod Arthur it is
of troth they are gretely to be doubted. Sir said Hector let us go to them and
give them their welcome Verily said the master now shall be seen who is a noble
man, verily I am sone to a king therefore ought I by reason to love deeds of
chyualry and to bear harneys, therefore because of this matter I would fayn be
made a knight. and tha^ I would gladly sir Hector go in your company to bydde
yonder galauntes welcome, for I would be loath yt ye should go and I to tarry
behind. And when ye bishop herd the master say yt he would be made a knight
he had thereat great laughter and sport and said, master by the good lord it
is much better to be in a chamber with ladies and damoyselles than to be
yonder without and to abide the breking of sharp speres, and it is hard to
find a clerk to be a good knight. well sir said the master all yt makes no
matter, for I trust to do so well yt I shall bring in one day in to this
place.ii. of those kings prisoners, than they all yt herd him began to laugh
and so al yt day they sported them at ye masters words till it was time to go
to rest and than every man went to bed and took their restes till the next
morning, in the morning all these lords arose betymes and assembled them
together in the mids of the palace, tha^ Hector said to Arthur, cosyn yonder
people without has good lift to sleep, for there is none to wake them, by ye
good lord me thinks we be very slow, let us go to them and se how they do. In
the name of god quod sir Cleme^so^ so let it be for we do not our deuoyrs to
abide so long, therefore let us issu out and dele valiau^tly with the^. In the
name of god quod Arthur every man to harneis and so every man went to arm
the^. Florence was not at ye poyntment, but when she knew thereof she came to
them and said syrs what mean ye to do, this matter must be done wisely, for ye
know not preseisely as yet for what cause this great assembly be come about
this castle, peradventure they be come to do honor to our marriage between
Arthur and me, for I can not bileue that the king my fader be com on me in
harneys, wherefore in my mind it were not best to assail them first, but if
they assail us tha^ let us defend our self in the best wise we can, sir
marks ye are a noble man to goo on my message to the king my fader, wherefore
I pray you go to him and humbly comau^de me to his grace, and say yt I require
him to send me word of his mind, and why that he is come hyder in this manner
of wise at this time, I pray you mark well these words that I have said to you,
a wise man needs no teching, but and ye se that he will needs keep still his
froward mind to me ward, tha^ I will that ye say to his.iiii. kings and to
al his chyualry how that I send them word how that they be al my men and
subjects, wherefore if there be any of them so hardy to draw any sword
against me or against any of mine* tell the^ that by the faith that I owe to my
lady Egle^tyne my ^ere mother on whose soul Ihesu have mercy that I shall
cause them to be hanged by the necks though they be never so noble or
gentil, and after that I will ye inquire why this emperor is come thus in to my
realm, and if ye se that he be come for our ill and that he would have
battle, show him prysysely that he shall have bataile right sharp and strong
to morrow betymes without any longer delay. In the name of God said duke Philyp
I se well we have a good heed of our house, madam ye follow right well the noble
steps of your lygnage. well madame said ye marks I trust I shall so fulfill
your message yt ye shall be content^ and so he took his leave of Florence and of
all the hole barony and rode forth till he came before the king Emendus at which
time he was accompanied with his.iiii. kings, and also there was the emperor
and all his kings and other dukes earls, barons, and knights, there was also
the king Jonas and king Clamados and diverse other noble men pertaining to
the emperor. Than the gentle marks entered in to the same place and did salute
the king and al his company, and said, sir I am come to you fro my lady
Florence your daughter the most noble and gentyl lady living, who right
derely commends her unto your grace as to her own dear fader, and sir she is
gretely abashed of this great company in harneys that ye have brought hyder at
this time, for sir it is a great abasshement to a noble gentyl maiden to se so
many helmes and sheldes shyning against the son wherefore sir she requires you
to know your pleasure and mind. Than the king with a fyerse look said, sir
knight I will not receive her salutacyon, for I love her not at my heart, but I
hope to do her damage both of body and of goods. Sir said ye marks and for
what cause. Certainly said the king for she has done me shame and despyte, for
she has gone away fro me with a strange knight, and she is come to hyde her
self in this castle, and there folyshely she keeps company with this strange
knight the which is a shame to her for evermore, and also she has done me
despyte, for I had given her to this emperor to have been his wife, and she
will not follow my will, and therefore because of the shame that she has done me
and does yet like a false stru^pet I shall put her into a perpetual prison to
thentente that she shall do me never more shame, and I shall hang the ribawde
knight by the neck that caused her thus to do, for the despyte that she has
done to me I shall do her an other, for I will never depart hens till I have
brought this castle down to the hard earth. Tha^ the noble marks answered
and said, sir as touching the shame that ye lay against my lady for cominge into
this castle I shall answer you, sir my lady is of great nobleness and honor
and a queen called by the right of her mode^, wherefore it is right yt some
time she go and se her own country, and to take her pleasure of her own, and
sir in that she departed without your license was for fere and doubt of this
Emperor to whom ye have given her against her will and heart, for she doubted
lest that he would have had her against her will, and therefore the master by
his clergy made you to be abused at the church door, and sir she came not
hider so simply yt she ought to be blamed, for she brought with her duke Phylyp
and tharchebysshop, and well.v. hundred other knights in her company and sir
the bishop is here uncle and your brother, wherefore he would be as loath that she
should do any otherwise than well as your self would be, but that needs not to
be fered, for she is of such wisdom that she ca^ rule her self well enough,
for there is not a wyser lady again in all the world, and sir also duke Phylyp
has been always with her, and therefore such people as be daily with her can
report her deling and so can not you that knows nothing thereof, and yet there
is none that speaks any vylany of her but you y^ which thing sir me thinks
ye ought not to do, and sir in deed yo^der good knight Arthur is with her, and
though it be so that she has retained him to her servant I think therein she
has done wisely, and so have not ye done in letti^g him depart out of your
court, for he is the flower of all the chyualry of the world, and she by her
wisdom has retained him, for when he went out of your court he left not
his felaw behind him, and sir if she have a good knight retained unto her she
is not such a lady but that she is of such habilite that she may right well
guerdon him for his service, sir she is not come to this castle in the despyte
of you, nor yet for the love of him that ye so sore despise, but sir she did it
because y^ ye would give her to such a man as she never loved nor can not love
nor will not love as long as she lives, without it be by force, and sir she
is not so poor a lady but that and ye would give her never so rich a man
against her will yet ye may be sure there should never good life be long between
the^, and because that this emperor would have her and she loves him not,
therefore she is come to that most strong castle that she has where as she
cares neither for him nor yet for any other yt would do her any dyspleasure,
therefore sir take heed what ye do for ye know well yt ye would have her to do
clean contrary to that was destenyed to her in the mount perilous at her
natiuyte, and sir a thing predestynate is hard to be broken, but sir I shall
show you what ye shall do fro hens forth leave medlyng any ferder in this matter,
for of one thing I make a warant that there is in her company and host a great
nombre of the best knights of the world, sir leave this matter and dele like a
true king, and agree to y^ promise that ye were before accorded unto, and y^
was who so ever should have the caplet of the image should in likewise rejoice
my lady Florence your daughter, and to this ye have written your hand and set
to your seal, and in likewise has done al your.iiii. kings here present and
all the.xii. peers of your realm, now sir ye do against your own seal and
covenant that ye made like a king thus to send for your people in harneys to
assemble against a woman, the fader against the daughter it is unnatural and a
great shame it is no deed of a king to do against his own covenant and promise,
sir for gods sake forbere for doi^g of any hurt against your own child for
any singular love yt ye have to this emperor. Certainly said the king I will
not forbere my mind, for all the tresour of the world shall not cause me but
ye knight shall be hanged by the neck, and she put in to perpetual prison. well
sir said the ma^kes than begin when ye will, and do the best ye can peraue^ture
all shall not be as ye would have it, but nevertheless to you.iiii. kings and
to al y^ xii. peers and to al other knights y^ be here present I say unto you
all my lady Florence sends you word by me yt she meruayleth greatly yt ye be
come hyder in harneys to war against her considering that ye be all her
subjects and she is your right lady and mastres, therefore lords take good
head what ye do, for she straightly charge you that ye nor none of yours draw
no sword nor wepe^ against her nor none of hers, for and ye do she promyseth by
the faith y^ she owes to my lady Eglentine her dear mother y^ was, that there
is none of what degree so ever he be of but that she will cause him to be hanged
by the neck like a false traytoure, wherefore syrs by my counsel take heed
what ye do. Than the king of orqueney said to the king Emendus, sir ye cause
us to have great maruayl yt ye have somoned us to come hither in harneys to
make war agenst our natural lady and to do against our promesses writings and
seals, sir it is of troth I am your man and I ought to go with you whether so
eu^r ye will have me in any just quarrel, but reason nor right will not that I
should make war agenst our right lady, whose subjects and men we be and must
be, for she is and shall be our lady by just inheritance, but by y^ faith yt I
owe to god and to my crown of the realm of orqueney, neither I nor none of
mine shall move any war agenst her, and of the same accord were all the.iiii.
kings and.xii. peers, for each of them said that they would never bear
harneys agenst their own lady, nor do against their own promesses made before.
Than the king Emendus said, lords I ^an not tell what ye will do, but I
promise you all that I will never depart out of this place till I have destroyed
this castle and all the knights y^ be therein hanged by the necks. And they al
answered him and said, sir do as it pleseth you, and we shall give you the
lokyng on, but we will not help thereto nor none of ours. Than the marks said
to the emperor, sir my lady would fayn know why ye be thus entered into her realm
with such nu^bre of men of war. Certainly sir said themperoure I am come
hither to seek her as for mine own, for she is given to me by her father and
because that she denies my will therefore I am come hider to have her wheder she
will or no, and I will do worse to her than I would do to a false traitor and I
shall hang by the neck yt rybaude knight that keeps her at his pleasure, and
duke Philyp of saboty also who does sustain her in her folysshe mind. And
when the king of orquen^y herd themperou^ menase and threte and say so of his
n^uewe duke Philyp he said, ye sir emperor fair and easily for or ye can
bring yt about ye shall have no cap nor hat too put on your head, for though yt
she be given to you yet she is not delivered to you, ye man well muse on her
delyu^raunce, but I ensure you ye get her not so lightly as ye wene, and sir as
for the knight whom ye do menase to hang by y^ neck, sir it were a great sin
so to do, for his nourisshing cost him more than so but sir take to morrow
some appointment between him and you to do some deeds of arms togider or else
take part of his men and so shall ye do of his, and than and ye ca^ take him
bind him fast, and than hang him by y^ neck and tha^ shall ye be clean out of
suspection between Florence and him, for tha^ ye may be sure he shall trespass
you no more, sir love has brought you hither, but ye nor al your knights are
nothing worth without ye do some deeds to be praised, sit mount on your horse to
morrow* for love governs you my lady is so fair, and she would gladly se you
give some fa^t stroke with your sword for her love for always good knights
gets grace among fair ladies, therefore sir to morrow wyn her amourous grace
with some deed of chiualry for in good faith ye have it not. well quod
the emperor get me ye knight yt sporteth hi^ so with her. Ye sir quod the mark
she will not so lightly beget, for sir he is within and ye be without in the
rain, and he is in the shadow abiding in the sight of this fair ladi y^
which is a great shame to you therefore put him out of this castle and get your
self in, but sir how say ye, shall this assemble be made to morrow or not. By my
faith said the emperor I shall make him assemble to morrow of.iiii. thousand,
and also of.xviii. M. men of arms. Sir said yt marks will ye promise this
faithfully. Ye truly said the emperor. And I promise faithfully for the other
parti said the marks y^ ye shall be received, and than he spoke as loud as he
could and said, lords and fre^des such as be subjects to my lady Florence y^
on pain of your lives yt ye move not nor make no w^r against my lady Florence
nor agenst (...) o^ hers, and than he said to the emperor sir for gods sake
begin the batail betymes because of the hete. Than the king Clamedos said to ye
marks, is this lady Florence so fair as it is said. A sir said the marks,
think ye nothing on her, for your emperor does enough for you hothe. well
friend said the king, I here say she has with her a sweet little rose white
tender and young, who is called Floret. Sir said the marks in deed there is
such one with my lady, and I ensure you she is right sweet, and she makes
oftentimes for me and such other knights of my company goodly chaplets and
sir as yet to my knowledge she has no love nor paramout and sir me think ye
have a jolly wanton eye, therefore sir come and se her to morrow, for she shall
be on the walls of the castle, and I shall show her unto you if I ca^ mete with
you, and sir when ye have seen her set your fete together and assay if ye can
lepe up to her, take on you to morrow this enterprise for the emperor, with a
good will said he, and said to the emperor, sir I require you let me have the
batail to morrow. well quod the emperor since ye will needs I am content, and so he
took his glove in pledge, and ye king thanked him, and the marks departed, and
went to the castle and recou^ted to Florence and to Arthur word for word as ye
have herd before, than they answered yt they had of him a right good
messenger, and granted him the ba^ail the next dai with xxx. M. agenst the king
Clamados.

How Philip duke of sabary and master Steven son to the king of valefou^d were
made knights, and of the discomfiture yt Arthur made on the emperor. Ca. lxxxx.
ANd when duke Philyp of sabary herd how yt they should have a battle the next
day in the morninge he said to the lady Florence, madame I require you let me
be made a knight, for I may not be in the place where as so many noble men be
without I were a knight By the faith that I owe to god said Florence with a right
good will. Than master Steven stepte forth and said, madame my lord the
archbisshop here present reputeth me but as one more metely to beat furs than
knights, but madam by the faith that I owe to god I would feign be made a
knight, and thereof I require your grace, and than every body began too laugh*
well sir quod he laugh not thereat for I ^ape not, I will be made a knight and I
may, than he went to the lady Margaret of Argenton and said to her in her
ear, mine own dear lady will it not plese you that I be made a knight, I
beseech you give me leave to be one, and she answered him fair and softly in
counsel and said, yes ywys sweet love I would be be glad thereof, than he rose
fro her and said alowde, my lady Margarete of Argento^ how say ye shall I be
made a knight. Certainly friend quod she I would be glad there of, on the
condycyon that ye will take armitre and horse and other abileme^tes of my gyf^.
Madam said he I thank you and I shall be glad to follow your pleasure with the
license of my lady Florence. Certainly quod Florence I am con^ent therwt. And
wha^ al ye other lords and knights saw that the master mened godd faith they
were right glad thereof, and so went as far that night to their restes and in
the morning for duke Philip Florence prepared horse and harneys and al other
abileme^tes, and fair lady Margaret ordained in like wise for master Steven,
tha^ tharchbishop sange y^ mass, and Arthur did gyrde on the masters sword,
and Hector did on duke Philips, than Arthur and Ceme^son led forth the master
between the^, and Hector and sir Perdi^as led forth duke Philip, and so they
offered to the bishop, and he did give them ye neck strokes of knighthode
according to the usage yt was than in y^ country, than Arthur and Hector armed
the^, and tha^ caused a great horn to be blown, and by the sowninge thereof
euery^ knight went to their harnes, and tha^ they took their leaves of Florence,
and than Arthur said to the marks and to sir Cla^e^ bait and to sir oaths,
syrs I pray you go and fortify the gates of this castle with.iiii C. pauess^s,
and so they did, and tha^ they issued out of the castle in good ordinance and
Arthur ordained their bataile right strong and marvelous, in y^ first battle
there was him self sir Brysebar and sir Cleme^son, and in their company.vii. M
hawbertes, and they were commanded to keep their right way under the mou^tayn

with them, and the master and duke Philyp and sir Perdycas went about the

host mast reken twice, and so did he ^or he failed of his enterprise* than the

and the king Clamados arden^d.iii. batails and therle of thy^e ^^^me did led
y^ first batail, and the duke ^^^alion with him* and they had in their company.x.

How that the emperor spoke with queen Proserpine, wenyng to him that it had
been the fair lady Florence, but he was deceived, for she did set a great
dyscorde between hi^ and the king Emendus as ye shall here after. Cap. lxxxxi.
When y^ the emperor and his company were ready aparailed they lept on their

unarmed and al other in like wise, than the tables were spread and every man

How that after the emperor was thus departed in dyspleasure and had defied the
king with mortal war the next night following by the subtle art of
master Steven all the kings host was brought every man fast a sleep, and in
the mean time the master and five other knights with him bare the king
Eme^dus fast a sleep as he lay, bed and all up in to the palace of the
Castle of the port noyre. Capitulo.lxxxxii.
THus as the king Emendus and his lords were in their tents right sore
troubled and abashed of the debate yt was risen between the king and
the emperor for the love of Proserpyne as ye have herd here before all that
season Arthur and his company were in the castle laughing and having good
game of the beginning of the occasyon of the strife between the king and the
emperor, and so all that day they were in great feast and joy till it was time
to go to their restes, and so every man went thereto save the master, and he
was in his doublet because that the weder was somewhat hot, and in his company
there was duke Phylyp, Brysebar, Gouernar, Hector, and Clemenson, and Perdycas,
and they played and sp^rted them togider til it was ver^ late, than Gouernar
said to the master, sir yonder in the heaven ye may se many sterres, but I pray
you how can ye know by them what should fall after. Sir said the master ye
science thereof is right pleasant and goodly. I pray your master said Hector
look now up in to the heaven and behold the planettes and look and ye can
perceive any thing that should auau^tage or else hurteful to us, and so for
their pleasure the master looked up and beheld ye heaven a great space, and at
last he said, lords and friends and ye be held the planettes and could
consider them as well as I do ye should clearly perceive that we be at the end of
our war, for we shall have shortly peace, and as I think verily we shall have
Arthur to our lord and master. Sweet master said duke Phylyp and I pray you
how shall all this come to pass. Verily sir I se well by ye course of the
sterres many meruayles, for ye planet that as now re^neth who has the
governance over the king Emendus is now in that point yt if we might have
the king we should lightly have peace with him, and I know well by the planet
that he is as now laid in his bed in his pauylyon and is fast a sleep and
all his host, and I know such a charm that if I do cast it, neither he nor
none of his shall awake till it be to morrow fair day, therefore let us go out
in to the field and bring hither the king, and than shall we have our peace
sone made. In ye name of god said Brisebar shame have he that fails so to do.
Let us go straight way said Gouernar, than they all aparayled them and went
out of the castle as pryuely as they could, and desire the marks to keep the
gates open till they returned, and when they approached nere to the tents,

myste, so that they loost clean the sight of the ^entes, and therewith every man
that was waking in the field fell fast a sleep, than the master and his

can yt be, how is he come thither, or how should he be a sleep among his enemies
Sir truly we have this night borne him to the castle in his bed fast a

Madame quod the king of mormal there is not so hard a herted man but yt a

How that king Emendus wha^ that he awoke forgave all his ill will to Florence
his daughter, and did put all the gouernynge of his realm into her hands.
Capitulo.lxxxxiii.
THus as Florence sat on her faders beds fete a good space, at last the
king felt one sitting on his beds fete therewith he awoke and opened his
eyes, and beheld the great wyndowes open before him fair glased and the sone
shynynge all about the chamber the which was hanged right rychely, than the
king meruayled gretely where he was and was sore afraid and blessed him of
tentymes and said, saint marye where am I, what am I betrayed, that art thou
that syttest on my beds fete. Sir said she I am your daughter Florence, and
when the king perceived that it was she he said, who has brought the in to
this place where as I am sith thou haste shamed thy self with a fugityue
knight. A sir said Florence for gods sake say ye so no more for by the holy
baptim that I received at the fon^e stone and on the dampnacion of my soul my
body was never by him nor by none other enpayred neither in word nor in deed.
Certainly said the king fool as thou art I believe the not, why have thou
else ben so much in his company without doing of any other thing, for look
where as the ^^rt is there is the body habandoned, for the body enclyneth to
the heart. why said Florence it needs not always to accomplysh^ all the
wylles of the heart, but such as are honorable and good. Sir said the king
what honor is this for you thus to hold your self in prison privily hid
with a strange knight, and to leave such a noble marriage as I would have given
to you Sir said she if it please you I ^hal show you as to that I have left you
and come h^der, it is of troth I saw well ye were of the mind to have given me
in marriage to this emperor the which truly was against my mind for I have
him to the death, in so much that I would it had cost me the one half of my
lands so that I had his heed fro his sholdres, so that I should not offend
god, and sir in this great hate read if I should have taken him my heart should
never have b^n in peace til I had caused him peraue^ture to have lost his life,
and thereby should I have been reputed a false murderer and dampened my soul
perpetually, and to you this should have been a great shame and reproach for I am
sure if I should have died in the quarrel I should have said gramercy to him yt
would have brought me his heed, for I am in fere I should have put my soul in
i^opardy to have gone to the devil of hell, and as fynding in some manner of
ways to have shorted his mortal life, and so in this I should have become
cruel, and lost my woman's heart, sir I ensure you this was my will and
entencion, and sir to eschew al these perils and inconuenyentes I am come

How that Arthur and the master, Hector, Gouernar, and sir Brysebar entered

When that Arthur and his.iiii. felawes were armed they mounted on their horses

a.lx. sarasins all armed, than Arthur went down to the valey again to his

how shall we be demened. Sir said Brisebar there is no more to do but let us
mount on our horses and do as knights should do, sir there is none of us but yt
is well worth a knight. well said Arthur now yt shall be seen, for yonder comes
a.lx. or moo of out enemies to awake us if we sleep. Let them com said

How truse was taken for a month between the emperor and Arthur. Ca. C.i.
ANd than Arthur out of a wi^dow called down to the emperor and said, sir
emperor ye do your self great shame and vylany, ye have ill counsel thus to
come on a woman by stelth, and under thassurance of truse that was taken
between my lord her fader and you thus to cause so number of people to come on
her sir if there were in you either valor or troth ye would not thus have
done, first ye should have given her warninge, and have made your defyaunce,
and have given her certain day of battle, and than to have taken her if ye
might, this sir should have been your honor, and not thus to awayte her in her
chamber with all this number of people, and she nothing knowing thereof before.
well said the emperor what so ever thou art thy tongue is fair fyled, would to
god I ^ad ye head of thine yt lokest so black. why sir said Arthur and would
ye than so feign have my head. Truly said the emperor on ye condition I would it
had cost me one years rent of al my lands. Ye sir said Arthur than give this
lady a certain day of battle that she may in the mean season send for her
people so yt she may answer you, and sir I promise you that I will be there and
than get my head and ye can. Truly said the emperor I am content, but what
assurance shall I have that ye will be there. Sir said Arthur by the faith yt I
owe unto my special lady. well said the emperor and I give her day for a month,
and truse in the mean season and so than the assurance was made on both
parties, than Arthur said holding Florence by the hand sir emperor behold
what a Jewel this is, sir ought not a man to b^ right jolly to obtain such a
lady so tender so sweet so ^uddy of color. Than ye emperor was sore displesed
and said: what you pratyng fool me thinks thy by sage is covered over with
black cordewan would to god I had the in my keeping, sir said Hector all smylyng
^ake no head of his saying for he is but a fool, than the emperor departed and
went to his tent, than Arthur said to Florence, madame we have now truse with
the emperor* so that we may well provide for men or the trewse breke^ for the
t^rme thereof is a monethe. well sir quod Florence I thank you thereof and of
the pain yt ye and your company has taken this day for my sake, but sir I
shall deserve it when I may. Madame it is al ready deserved, but madame may it
plese you to leave the loving of the knighte yt ye say ye love so well and take
me to your lover and give me your love, and I promise you I shall deliver you
from this emperor for this other knight is now in france in great sport, and
thinks but litell on you, for he has many fair ladies in his country at his
commandment. Sir said Florence his sport and joy is a great pleasure to my
heart, for I am his both with heart thought and body, and never to be falls to
him, for as help me god I had rather suffer my head to be stricken of than I
should do or think any falsenes to him. why madame love ye than him so inwardly
and so truly. Ye or else said she I pray to god I never have joy in this
world. well than said he I se well that my love can not prevail. No be ^e sure

wise the master prayed the lady Margar^t of her love desyryng her to love him
and to forsake the clerk. And she answered yt to dye in the pain she would
never be false to him. Th^n Arthur said to the master let us leave these

Madame by the faith that I owe unto you master Steven, and there recounted to

Hector were comen in to the castle than they were in their minds better

recounte to him how that we have spedde, and how that we have truse for the

Emendus shall not think that I am ill bestowed on you sir I require you let me
se them as shortly as ye can tha^ Gouernar took his leave and departed toward

How that the young king of malogre and the duke of ^ritayne with diverse

How that king Jonas al alone came to the castle of the clear toure, and there
did his message from the emperor of ynde the more. Capitulo.C.iii.
THan king Jonas issued out of the emperors host al armed well and fresshely
mounted, and so all alone without any company he came to the clear toure, and
under a fair olyue tree he alyghted and mounted up into the palace, and there

be rased down to ye hard earth and thy self burnt in a fair fire and the

How that the emperor and king Jonas accompanied with fyfty^ thousand men of
war came to the clear toure for to have made assaute thereto, and than they
found the gates open and entered both into the town and in to the castle,
for they thought verily that all the frensshe men had been fled, but they were
deceived, for than the frensshe men lepte out from their enbusshementes and
shette fast the gates* and there slew king Jonas and all the fyftye
thousand, so that none escaped alive but one and the Emperor who was taken
prisoner. Capitulo.C.iiii.
IN the morning wha^ king Jonas saw the day begin to spring he lept out of his
bed and made to be cried thrughout al his host ye eueri man should to harne is
to ye e^ntent to make assaut to the clear toure, tha^ king Jonas assembled there

frensshe men has left behind them much bagage there as there were lodged with

How that the emperor dyed in prison for sorrow when that he knew that his
kings and people were al slain and dyscomfyted. Capitulo.C.viii.
SO it was that when the king of mormal^es body was brought in to the church
within the castle, there was made right great sorrow in all the city and castle,
in so much that themperoure as he lay in his bed sore sick, for he enpayred
every day more and more, and as he lay he herd the great sorrow yt was made without
in the castle, than he demanded what it was and wherefore that great bruyte wi^h
out was made, and than it was showed hi^ how that it was because of the death of
ye king of mormal who was slain by king Floripes. Ye said themperor and how
does king Florypes. I charge you tell me the troth. Sir for goods sake
inquire no more of that matter till ye be perfect hole I will not said
the emperor I will know it, but than he said to a subject of his own that was
there with him, I charge the to tell me the plain troth, sir since it plese you I
shall tell you the plain troth, it is so i^ deed al your people are destroyed,
and your brother king Floropes and al your other kings are al slain, and when
the emperor herd that he had so great sororw that he closed his tethe together and
cast his hands abroad, and therewith his heart did ryue asonder and so dyed for
sorrow, and than such as were about him did cast out a great cry, than
Florence and the duke of britain went into the same chaumbre and there they
found the emperor ded, tha^ the duke of britain sent for king Alexander and the
king of orqueney and for all the other lords and barons, and when they were al

Florypes and laid by them, than incontinent there went a messenger to king

said to him, sir themperor is in prison and al his hosts discom^ited, and al
hi^ kings dead and slaiu tha^ the king demanded whoo had done those noble
deeds, sir said he as god help us yt has done such knights as Arthur has

has made an end of all his enemies, how be it sir there is one great mischefe

How after the marriage of Arthur the barons and ladies of france returned
into their own countries except king Alexander whom king Emendus kept still and
made unto him great ^here, and he tarried there so long till that Florence was
delivered o^ a fair son who king Alexander held on the fon^. Ca C.xiiii.
AFter that these.vii. days we refynysshed than the french lords ladies and

she would gladly have gone with the^ saving for keeping of company with the king

Gouernar did convey them a little way, than the duke of brytayne said to

and Arthur promised him so to do, and than he took his leave of the duches his
mother and kissed each other with weping ^yen, so than the duke and the duches
took their way homeward and Arthur and Gouernar returned to the king, and found
him and king Alexander together, for king Emendus had so entreted king
Alexander that he promised him to abide in his company for a certain space,
and so he abode there so long in great mirth and pleasure till at last the noble
queen Florence was brought a bed and had a fair son* And on a fair day as

quen^ Florence is brought a bed of a fair son, wherefore he desires you to

How king Alexander returned into his country and led with him Arthur Gouernar*
Hector and master Steven, ^atye^ in britayne so long till Florence sent for
Arthur because y^ her father king Emendus was departed this ^i^e wherefore ^he

When that king Alexander had been a long season with king Emendus he took
leave of him and returned into france, and there went with him Arthur,
Gouernar, Hector and master Steven, and within a while after that they were
departed king Emendus, what for the great Joy yt he had of his son and for
such labor as he took before he fell seek and lay in his bed, and as the
story says he lay but.vii. wekes but that he dyed, and King Alexander and
such other as went with him rode so long by their Iourneys till at last they
aryued in the land of brytayn, than a messenger went before to the duke and
showed how yt they would be with him on the monday next coming. And when the
duke herd that he was never so ioyefull before, than the duke sent for all his
lords and ladies of his country yt they should be with him at ye receyuynge of
his son Arthur and of such other as came with him, and so they did, and the
same day Arthur aryued there and was received with great f^est and joy the
which feast endured.viii. days, than all they co^uayed king Alexander in to
his own realm. It needs not to be demanded wh^der that Arthur and his
company had there good chere or not.

How Arthur was sent for because of the death of king Eme^dus, and how yt he was
crowned king of soroloys. Ca. C.xvi.
ARthur and his company were a great season with king Alexander and had right
good chere and on a day as he sat at the table there came in a messe^ger fro
his lady Florence, and he kneled down and arthur did arise and went to him and
received of him a letter sent to him fro Florence the which arthur incontinent
did break up, and therein he found how that the mighty king Emendus was dead,
whereof he and all that company made right great sorrow, than arthur desired king
Alexander yt he would go with him again into the realm of Soroloys, and he
granted him so to do with a right good heart, so tha^ incontine^t they
apparayled for their departing, and so mounted on their horses and did so much
by their Iourneys yt they aryued in ye realm of Sorolois, and there they
found Florence making right great sorrow for the death of the king her fader
but as soon as she saw her lord Arthur her heart revived, in such wise that
she forgot in a manner half her sorrow, than the next day the corpse was borne
to the church, and with great solempnite there he was ryally buried as it
appertayned to such a noble prince, than wtin a while after king Alexander
said that it was time to make purueyau^ce for Arthurs crownacion, than there
was sent for all the kings, dukes earls, barons, knights and squyers and al
their kin and friends and there came thither people without nombre, tha^
arthur was there with great triumph crowned with gold and took homage of
every man, and after his crownacion the feast endured.viii. days every man
making great joy save Florence who was still in great sorrow for the death of
her fader, and after this great feast and joy and that every man had made
homage to arthur for their kingedomes, dukedomes and baronies and for all their
lands, than every man departed into their own countries, and ever after
arthur, Gouernar Hector, and the master loved each other and held so fast
together that none of their enemies di^^^e never approach on none of them, and
so they used their lives in great honor and love, and peace and union was ever
between the^ and their subjects for as long as they lived there was never
none of that ever moved any war against them, thus arthur and Florence
reigned in great prosperity, ^rad and sore doubted of all the world, and did
many fair conquestes, for he conquered or he died.viii. realms and diverse
countries and rich seygnoryes, but he lived not long after

Here is devised how long that arthur lived* and how that he was buburied.
Cap. C.xvii.
THe history recounteth that the noble Arthur lived but.xxxii. year and tha^
he died, and the queen Florence whom he loved so well dyed for sorrow and so
they were both buried with great so^empnite, and laid both in the tomb with
king Emendus, on the which tomb there was wryte^ this epitaphe, here lies
the mighty king Eme^dus Arthur and Florence his wife who led so good life
together that they were never dyspleased either with other, and Gouernar, Hector
and the master made great sorrow for the death of Arthur and the young
Alexnader son to arthur, and to Florence was in the guydyng of king Gouernar,
of Hector, and of the gentle master Steven, who afterward was Emperor of
ynde and of Constantinoble, and thus ends the hystory of the valya^^te knight
Arthur son to the duke of Brytayne, and of the noble lady Florence daughter to
the mighty king Eme^dus king of the realm of Soroloys. And all those that
redeth or hereth this history I pray god send them bliss perdurable. Amen.

Here ends the hystory of Arthur of little Brytayne.
Imprynted at London in Powles church yeard at the sign of the Cock by
Roberte Redborne.
